{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Curtis Culwell Center attack | image = Palacio de Convenciones.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Curtis Culwell Center | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | location = [[Garland, Texas]], U.S. | target = [[Stop Islamization of America|American Freedom Defense Initiative]] exhibition |coordinates = {{Coord|32.95956|N|96.64191|W|display=inline,title|region:US-TX_type:event}} | date = {{start date|2015|05|03}} | time = 6:50 p.m. | timezone = [[UTC−05:00]] | type = [[Shooting]], [[terrorist attack]] | fatalities = 2 (both perpetrators) | injuries = 1 (security officer) | perpetrators= Elton Simpson and Nadir Soofi{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/04/us/garland-mohammed-drawing-contest-shooting|title=Garland, Texas, shooting suspect linked himself to ISIS in tweets|work=CNN|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} | susperps = [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]]
[[Joshua Ryne Goldberg]]{{cite web | website=BBC News | title=Neo-Nazi, radical feminist and violent jihadist - all at once | date=September 21, 2015 | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-34292809}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/internet-troll-joshua-goldberg-attempted-to-incite-terror-attacks-in-melbourne/news-story/07986e685672651e62edca37295fad4f|title=Internet troll Joshua Goldberg attempted to incite terror attacks in Melbourne|work=news.com.au|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en}}{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/09/10/us/9-11-memorial-bomb-plot-kansas-city-missouri/|title=Man accused of bomb plot at 9/11 event, FBI says - CNN.com|author=Ralph Ellis and Greg Botelho, CNN|date=September 10, 2015|accessdate=September 10, 2015|work=CNN}} | weapons = *Three [[Semi-automatic rifle]]s *Three [[handgun]]s | motive = Retaliation for [[depictions of Muhammad]] }} The '''Curtis Culwell Center attack''' was carried out by two Americans from Arizona who attacked officers with gunfire at the entrance to an exhibit featuring cartoon [[images of Muhammad]] at the [[Curtis Culwell Center]] in [[Garland, Texas]] on May 3, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2015/05/03/breaking-shooting-in-garland|title=BREAKING: Shooting At Muhammad Art Exhibit In Garland « CBS Dallas/Fort Worth|publisher=dfw.cbslocal.com|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} The attackers shot a [[Garland Independent School District]] (GISD) security officer in the ankle. Shortly after the attackers pulled up and opened fire, both were promptly shot and killed by an off duty Garland police officer working as mall security.{{cite web|url=https://www.policeone.com/active-shooter/articles/419451006-Cop-shares-gunfight-lessons-from-ISIS-inspired-Draw-the-Prophet-terrorist-attack/|title=Cop shares gunfight lessons from ISIS-inspired 'Draw the Prophet' terrorist attack |date=March 30, 2017|accessdate=Feb 24, 2018}} The FBI had been monitoring the two attackers for years and an undercover agent was right behind them, filming with his camera, when the first shots were fired. The agent was himself arrested and later released.{{cite web|url=http://dailycaller.com/2017/03/27/fbi-undercover-agent-was-in-car-behind-terrorists-and-failed-to-stop-attack/|title=FBI Undercover Agent Was In Car Behind Terrorists And Failed To Stop Attack|date=Mar 27, 2017|accessdate=Feb 24, 2018}} The security guard who was wounded filed a lawsuit against the FBI in October 2017, claiming the FBI was partially responsible for his injuries.{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/victim-of-draw-muhammad-isis-inspired-terror-attack-sues-fbi-accuses-james-comey-of-cover-up/article/2636321|title="Victim of 'Draw Muhammad' ISIS-inspired terror attack sues FBI, accuses James Comey of cover-up" |date=Sep 15, 2017|accessdate=Feb 2, 2018}} The [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL) claimed responsibility for the attack plot, the first time the militant group took credit for an attack in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/nation/2015/05/05/prophet-cartoon-contest-shooting/26910391|title=Doubts raised about Islamic State claim in Texas attack|author=Julie Watson|date=May 5, 2015|agency=Associated Press}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-32589546|title=IS says it was behind US Prophet cartoon attack|publisher=BBC|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/11581345/Islamic-State-supporters-claim-responsibility-for-Texas-attack.html|title=Texas shooting: Islamic State claims responsibility for first US attack as gunmen named|publisher=The Telegraph|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/isis-claims-responsibility-for-texas-muhammad-cartoon-contest-shooting|title=ISIS claims responsibility for Texas attack|publisher=CBS News|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} ISIL's claim of responsibility has not been verified, and U.S. officials stated that the attack appears to have been inspired, but not directed, by ISIL. An online ISIL persona run by [[internet troll]] [[Joshua Ryne Goldberg]] had posted maps to the exhibition, and urged his followers to attack the event. Goldberg pled guilty to federal charges in December 2017. His persona was retweeted by one of the attackers on the morning of the attack, and Goldberg claimed responsibility for inciting the attack to multiple news outlets and in his plea agreement. ==Background== ===Muhammad exhibit and contest=== The event, which featured [[images of Muhammad]], was advertised as the "First Annual Muhammad Art Exhibit and Contest", presented by the [[Stop Islamization of America|American Freedom Defense Initiative]] (AFDI), or Stop Islamization of America. It was organized by the AFDI together with the [[David Horowitz Freedom Center]]'s [[Jihad Watch]], run by [[Robert Spencer (author)|Robert Spencer]].{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/05/09/us-usa-shooting-businessman-exclusive-idUSKBN0NU0G620150509|title=Exclusive: Why a company chairman supported a Prophet Mohammad cartoon event|work=Reuters|date=May 9, 2015|author1=Tim McLaughlin|author2=Mark Hosenball}} A $10,000 award was offered for the winning cartoon, which was selected from among 350 submissions. The prize was awarded to [[Bosch Fawstin]], a former Muslim and a [[Criticism of Islam|critic of Islam]] who submitted six drawings, with the text "You can't draw me!"/"That's why I draw you."{{cite news|title="That's Why I Draw You": An Interview with Bosch Fawstin|url=http://theundercurrent.org/thats-why-i-draw-you-an-interview-with-bosch-fawstin/|work=the Undercurrent|date=May 26, 2015}} He was to collect an award of $12,500.{{cite web|url=http://www.americanthinker.com/blog/2015/05/the_muhammad_cartoon_that_won_the_draw_muhammad_contest.html|title=The Muhammad cartoon that won the Draw Muhammad contest|publisher=American Thinker|author=Thomas Lifson|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://thescoopblog.dallasnews.com/2015/05/garland-cartoon-contest-winner-reacts-to-shooting-they-came-to-kill-us-and-died-for-it-justice.html|title=Garland cartoon contest winner reacts to shooting: "They came to kill us and died for it. Justice."|work=The Dallas Morning News|author=Naheed Rajwani|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://dailycaller.com/2015/05/03/breaking-shooting-in-texas-outside-of-muslim-cartoon-event-attended-by-geert-wilders|newspaper=Daily Caller|title=Shooting in Texas Outside of Muslim Cartoon Event|author=Chuck Ross|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} Though [[Depictions of Muhammad|images of Muhammad]] are not explicitly banned by the [[Quran]], prominent Islamic views [[aniconism in Islam|oppose human images]], especially those of prophets. Such views have gained ground among certain militant Islamic groups.{{citation|work=Newsweek|date=January 9, 2015|url=http://www.newsweek.com/koran-does-not-forbid-images-prophet-298298|title=The Koran Does Not Forbid Images of the Prophet}}{{cite news|last1=Burke|first1=Daniel|title=Why Islam forbids images of Mohammed|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/01/07/living/islam-prophet-images|accessdate=January 16, 2015|date=January 9, 2015|publisher=BBC}}{{cite news|title=The issue of depicting the Prophet Muhammad|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-30813742|accessdate=January 16, 2015|publisher=BBC|date=January 14, 2015}} The event featured speeches by [[Pamela Geller]], president of the AFDI, and [[Geert Wilders]], a Dutch lawmaker known for his outspoken criticism of Islam. Congressmen [[Keith Ellison]] and [[André Carson]], both Muslims,{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2015/01/13/376998473/congressman-andr-carson-to-become-first-muslim-on-house-committee-on-intelligenc|title=Andre Carson to become first Muslim on House Committee on Intelligence|work=NPR|date=January 13, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/keith-ellison-213034 |title=Keith Ellison profile |work=biography.com |accessdate=May 5, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150417104647/http://www.biography.com/people/keith-ellison-213034 |archivedate=April 17, 2015 }} had tried unsuccessfully to block Wilders from entering the United States.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2015/04/29/congressmen-keith-ellison-and-andre-carson-call-for-denial-of-visa-to-dutch-legislator-geert-wilders|title=Congressmen Keith Ellison and André Carson call for denial of visa to Dutch legislator Geert Wilders|date=April 29, 2015|author=Eugene Volokh|author-link=Eugene Volokh|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} Wilders is currently on an [[Al-Qaeda]] hit-list following the release of ''[[Fitna (film)|Fitna]]'', a 2008 short film that he wrote.{{cite web|url=http://www.wptv.com/news/national/overmatched-officer-stops-2-heavily-armed-men-at-the-curtis-culwell-center-in-garland-texas|title=Overmatched officer stops 2 heavily-armed men at the Curtis Culwell Center in Garland, Texas|work=WPTV|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} The event was motivated by [[Charlie Hebdo shooting|the terrorist attack]] on the [[List of satirical magazines|satirical weekly magazine]] ''[[Charlie Hebdo]]'' four months prior, and was the first of a planned annual contest. At the time of the attack, the "First Annual Muhammad Art Exhibit and Contest" exhibit was attended by approximately 150 people,{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/crime/headlines/20150511-garland-police-say-they-had-no-tip-about-attack-at-culwell-center.ece|title=Garland police say they had no tip about attack at Culwell Center|newspaper=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|date=May 11, 2015|first1=Naomi|last1=Martin|first2=Ray|last2=Leszcynski}} although the number was initially estimated at 200. The organizers of the event had paid over $10,000 to a total of forty off-duty police officers and private security guards. The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI), a [[SWAT]] team, the [[Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives]] (ATF), and the [[Texas Department of Public Safety]] (DPS) were also brought in for the occasion of any possible incidents.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/05/04/us-usa-shooting-texas-idUSKBN0NP01G20150504|title=Police raid home of gunman in Mohammad cartoon attack in Texas|publisher=Reuters|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} At the time, there was reportedly "no immediate credible threat" of an attack.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/shooting-vicinity-texas-community-center-hosting-draw-prophet/story?id=30777312|title=2 Gunmen Killed Outside Community Center Hosting 'Draw the Prophet' Show|work=ABC News|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} Prior to the attack, ISIL had urged followers and sympathizers who were unable to join the fighting in the [[Syrian Civil War]] to carry out [[jihad]] in their home countries. Approximately three hours prior to the start of the contest, the FBI had alerted the Garland Police Department that a suspected extremist, identified as gunman Elton Simpson, was "interested in the event" and could show up there. However, FBI officials later clarified they had no reason to believe an actual attack would occur at the contest.{{cite web|title=FBI sent alert about gunman before Texas shooting|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-32632513|work=BBC News|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=May 7, 2015}}{{cite web|title=FBI Was Aware Shooter Was Interested in Garland Event|url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/FBI-Was-Aware-Shooter-Was-Interested-in-Garland-Event-302976551.html|work=NBC DFW|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=May 7, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2015/05/07/fbi-warned-garland-police-before-attack/|title=FBI Warned Garland PD Before Muhammad Exhibit Shooting|work=CBS DFW|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=May 7, 2015}} Officers later stated that they were not aware of the alert.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/garland-police-discuss-muhammad-cartoon-contest-shooting-150555920.html|title=Chief: Memo wouldn't have changed cartoon contest response|work=Yahoo! News|date=May 11, 2015|accessdate=May 11, 2015}} ===Location=== The "First Annual Muhammad Art Exhibit and Contest" event was hosted at the [[Curtis Culwell Center]], rented from the [[Garland Independent School District]]. The center previously hosted a fundraiser in January called "Stand With the Prophet in Honor and Respect", which was organized to combat negative stereotypes of Islam.{{cite web|title=‘Stand With Prophet’ event in Texas draws thousands of protesters|last=Chasmar|first=Jessica|work=The Washington Times|date=January 18, 2015|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/jan/18/stand-with-prophet-event-in-texas-draws-thousands-|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} Geller had spearheaded about 1,000 picketers at that event.{{cite web|title=City: 2 gunmen killed outside Muhammad cartoon contest |last1=Merchant |first1=Nomaan |last2=Stengle |first2=Jamie |work=The Seattle Times |date=May 3, 2015 |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/officer-shooting-at-muhammad-cartoon-contest-in-texas |accessdate=May 4, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150521162524/http://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/officer-shooting-at-muhammad-cartoon-contest-in-texas/ |archivedate=May 21, 2015 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/community-news/garland-mesquite/headlines/20150504-some-fear-culwell-center-now-a-target-as-busy-graduation-season-nears.ece|title=As graduations near, some fear Garland ISD's Culwell Center now a target|work=The Dallas Morning News|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} Before the start of the "First Annual Muhammad Art Exhibit and Contest", concerns were expressed by Garland citizens about the center hosting the event due to potential backlash and retaliation, a sentiment that had also been voiced prior to the "Stand With the Prophet in Honor and Respect" event. However, officials allowed both events to proceed as planned, since the school district was bound by a nondiscriminatory leasing policy. Garland ISD board president Rick Lambert said in January, "The Culwell Center is available for rental as long as you comply with the law. Because it is a public facility, the district is not allowed to discriminate based upon viewpoint."{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/community-news/garland-mesquite/headlines/20150427-islam-debate-returns-to-garland-isds-culwell-center-with-muhammad-art-event.ece|title=Islam debate returns to Garland ISD’s Culwell Center with Muhammad art event|work=The Dallas Morning News|date=April 27, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} ==Attack== Minutes prior to the attack, a man, identified by police as one of the gunmen, posted a tweet with the hashtag #texasattack: "May [[Allah]] accept us as [[mujahideen]]." In his tweet, he said he and an accomplice had pledged allegiance to "[[Amirul Mu'mineen]]", which Paul Cruickshank of CNN said probably referred to ISIL leader [[Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi]]. The user also asked his readers to follow [[Junaid Hussain]] on Twitter. After the shooting occurred, Hussain tweeted: "[[Takbir#Jihadist usage|Allahu Akbar]]!!!! 2 of our brothers just opened fire." Just before the event was set to end at around 7:00{{nbsp}}p.m., two men wearing [[body armor]] and equipped with three rifles, three [[handgun]]s, and 1,500 rounds of ammunition drove up to a police car that was parked next to a barricade erected in front of the center. Seated inside the police car were Officer Gregory Stevens of the Garland Police Department and an unarmed Garland ISD security guard.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} The two gunmen got out of their vehicle and fired dozens of rounds at the police car, shooting the Garland ISD security guard. The men were then shot and wounded by Stevens, and eventually killed by four members of the SWAT team.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} The initial news reports mistakenly claimed that Officer Gregory Stevens killed the two gunmen.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/people-shot-texas-prophet-muhammad-art-exhibit-article-1.2208953|title=Two gunmen shot dead by cops after opening fire outside controversial 'Prophet Muhammad' art exhibit in Texas|work=New York Daily News|date=May 3, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/05/04/prophet-mohammed-cartoon-shootings-texas/26858741|title=Traffic cop killed both attackers at Mohammed exhibit in Texas|work=USA Today|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wfaa.com/story/news/crime/2015/05/03/garland-curtis-culwell-center-swat/26848435|title=Garland police: Suspects were 'there to shoot people'|work=WFFA|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/Shots-Fired-at-Prophet-Muhammad-Art-Event-302362751.html|title=Garland ISD Officer Injured, 2 Dead in Shooting Outside Culwell Center in Garland|publisher=nbcdfw.com|accessdate=May 4, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2015/05/03/breaking-shooting-in-garland/|title=2 Dead In Shooting At Muhammad Art Exhibit In Garland|work=CBS DFW|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/swat-team-killed-muhammad-cartoon-contests-gunmen-police-article-1.2218538|title=SWAT team killed Muhammad cartoon contest's gunmen, not lone officer: Texas police chief|work=New York Daily News|date=May 11, 2015|accessdate=May 12, 2015}} The Garland ISD officer, identified as 58-year-old Bruce Joiner, was shot in the ankle.{{cite web|url=http://www.wfaa.com/story/news/local/2015/05/03/garland-curtis-culwell-center-swat/26848435|title=2 gunmen shot dead outside Muhammad Art Exhibit in Garland|publisher=wfaa.com|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} He was treated at a local hospital and confirmed to be released at 9:00 p.m.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs19.tv/story/28965671/two-shot-near-muhammad-art-event-in-garland|title=2 dead after gunfire outside Muhammad cartoon exhibit in Garland|author=Gerardo Martinez|publisher=cbs19.tv|date=May 3, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} Authorities were worried that the suspects' car could contain an incendiary device; as a precaution, several nearby businesses were evacuated. Bomb units from the Garland Police Department, the FBI, the Plano Police Department, and the [[Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport]] were called to the scene. Police cordoned off a large area and at least three helicopters circled overhead.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2015/05/04/police-shooting-at-muhammad-cartoon-contest-in-texas|title=Two suspects killed, officer injured after shooting outside Muhammad cartoon contest in Texas|publisher=foxnews.com|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} An officer in SWAT gear took the stage toward the end of the event and told attendees that a shooting had occurred, stating that one officer and two suspects had been shot.{{cite web|url=http://fox4kc.com/2015/05/03/report-gunfire-erupts-outside-texas-anti-islam-event|title=Report: gunfire erupts outside Texas anti-Islam event|publisher=fox4kc.com|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} It was later confirmed that there were no explosives inside the vehicle.{{cite web|url=http://alaska-native-news.com/police-search-phoenix-apartment-of-curtis-culwell-center-attack-17166|title=Police Search Phoenix Apartment of Curtis Culwell Center Attack|work=Alaska Native News|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} After the attack, Phoenix police began searching the two assailants' apartment. ==Perpetrators== Elton Simpson ({{circa}} 1985 – May 3, 2015) and Nadir Hamid Soofi ({{circa}} 1981 – May 3, 2015), roommates living in an apartment in [[Phoenix, Arizona]], were the assailants in the attack. Simpson was convicted of making a false statement about terrorism in 2011, and followed hacker and pro-ISIL propagandist [[Junaid Hussain]] on [[Twitter]].{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/05/us/texas-shooting-gunmen|title=Who are the gunmen behind the Texas shooting?|author=Holly Yan, CNN|date=May 5, 2015|work=CNN}}{{cite web|url=http://heavy.com/news/2015/05/nadir-hamid-soofi-elton-simpson-phoenix-garland-muhammad-art-contest-shooting-suspect-terrorism-isis/|title=Nadir Hamid Soofi: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know|work=Heavy|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} Simpson was an employee at a dentist's office, while Soofi was running a carpet cleaning business.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-32582704|title=Profile: Texas gunmen Elton Simpson and Nadir Soofi|work=BBC News|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} A third man, Abdul Malik Abdul Kareem (born {{circa}} 1972), was responsible for housing Simpson and Soofi at his home, as well as supplying them with the firearms and ammunition used in the attack. According to an indictment, around June 2014, the three began conspiring to support ISIL and considered targeting a number of locations for terrorist attacks.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/16/us/garland-texas-prophet-mohammed-contest-shooting/|title=Man indicted for allegedly helping Mohammed cartoon contest attackers|work=CNN|date=June 17, 2015|accessdate=June 17, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/arizona-man-abdul-malik-abdul-kareem-charged-with-supporting-isis/|title=Arizona man involved in Texas attack charged with supporting ISIS|work=CBS News|date=December 24, 2015|accessdate=December 31, 2015}} ===Elton Simpson=== {{Infobox person |name = Elton Simpson |birth_name = Elton Simpson |birth_date = {{circa}} 1985 |birth_place = [[Illinois]], U.S. |death_date = May 3, 2015 (aged 29 or 30) |death_place = [[Garland, Texas]], U.S. |death_cause = Gunshot wounds |residence = [[Phoenix, Arizona]], U.S. |nationality = American |occupation = Dental office employee }} Simpson was born in [[Illinois]] and raised in suburban [[Westmont, Illinois|Westmont]].{{cite web|url=http://abc7chicago.com/news/elton-simpson-alleged-shooter-outside-prophet-cartoon-contest-from-illinois/695565/|title=ELTON SIMPSON, SHOOTER IN TEXAS PROPHET CARTOON CONTEST, FROM ILLINOIS|work=ABC 7 Chicago|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} He moved to Phoenix at a young age.{{cite web|url=http://heavy.com/news/2015/05/elton-simpson-garland-texas-muhammad-cartoon-shooter-gunman-name-phoenix-arizona-terrorist-twitter-tweets-photos-fbi-dead-death-video-atawaakul/|title=Elton Simpson: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know|work=Heavy|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} He converted to Islam while attending [[Washington High School (Phoenix, Arizona)|Washington High School]]. His lawyer described him as "particularly devout" and "entrenched in Islam", but said he did not seem to be a threat to anyone.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/suspect-in-texas-attack-previously-face-trial-on-terrorism-charge/2015/05/04/438df596-f279-11e4-bcc4-e8141e5eb0c9_story.html?hpid=z2|title=One Texas suspect was accused in 2010 FBI terror case|date=May 4, 2015|newspaper=Washington Post}} Simpson was a longtime worshiper at the [[Islamic Community Center of Phoenix]], starting in approximately 2005, but according to the mosque's president, Usama Shami,{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/phoenix/2015/05/07/texas-terrorist-shooting-phoenix-mosque-abrk/70954634/|title=Phoenix mosque is a familiar FBI target|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=May 30, 2015|work=The Arizona Republic}} he stopped showing up months prior to the attack.{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/crime/headlines/20150504-2-garland-shooters-lives-twined-to-tragic-end.ece|title=2 Garland shooters’ lives twined to tragic end|work=dallasnews.com|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/news/texas/article/2-gunmen-killed-outside-Muhammad-cartoon-contest-6240040.php |title=Accused Texas gunman well-known to FBI before attack |work=San Francisco Chronicle |date=May 4, 2015 |accessdate=May 4, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505040544/http://www.sfchronicle.com/news/texas/article/2-gunmen-killed-outside-Muhammad-cartoon-contest-6240040.php |archivedate=May 5, 2015 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.nltimes.nl/2015/05/04/american-terror-suspect-idd-in-texas-attack/|title=AMERICAN TERROR SUSPECT ID'D IN TEXAS ATTACK|work=NL Times|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://heavy.com/news/2015/05/elton-simpson-garland-texas-muhammad-cartoon-shooter-gunman-name-phoenix-arizona-terrorist-twitter-tweets-photos-fbi-dead-death-video-atawaakul|title=Elton Simpson: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know|author=Tom Cleary|work=Heavy.com|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://gma.yahoo.com/official-one-texas-shooting-suspects-ided-111112719--abc-news-topstories.html|title=Official: One of Texas Shooting Suspects IDed|work=Yahoo! News GMA|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} The mosque has been part of previous terrorism probes.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/05/07/phoenix-mosque-terror-probes/70965798/|title=Phoenix mosque is long-standing FBI target|date=May 7, 2015|author=Sean Holster|work=USA Today}} He attended [[Yavapai College]] in [[Prescott, Arizona]], playing basketball for the college there.{{cite news|url=http://jacksonville.com/breaking-news/2015-05-06/story/gunmans-hashtag-texasattack-hinted-texas-plot|title=Gunman's hashtag hinted at Texas plot|work=Jacksonville Times-Union|agency=Associated Press|date=May 6, 2015|accessdate=September 1, 2015}} Simpson was the subject of an FBI investigation starting in 2006, during which he stated his intent to travel to [[Somalia]] and join fellow [[jihadist]]s. He had ties to [[Hassan Abujihaad]], a former [[United States Navy]] sailor arrested in Phoenix and convicted of terrorism-related charges. Abujihaad had been an occasional attendant of the Islamic Community Center of Phoenix.{{cite news| author =Sean Holstege| title =Phoenix man guilty of aiding terrorists| quote =| newspaper =[[The Arizona Republic]]| date = March 6, 2008| url =http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/0306abujihaad0306.html| accessdate =May 11, 2015}} In May 2009, Simpson told an FBI informant, "I'm telling you, man, we can make it to the battlefield. It's time to roll." He was also recorded saying, "If you get shot, or you get killed, it's [heaven] straightaway... That's what we here for ... so why not take that route?" In 2010, one day before Simpson was scheduled to travel to Somalia, he was arrested by federal agents as the result of a four-year investigation. The Islamic Community Center of Phoenix posted cash bond of $100,000 to have him released from custody.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/05/06/what-drove-phoenix-duo-to-murderous-texas-plot/26967337/|title=What drove Phoenix duo to murderous Texas plot?|author=Sean Holstege and Matthew Casey, The Arizona Republic|date=May 6, 2015|work=USA TODAY}} Simpson was found guilty of making a false statement regarding international and domestic terrorism, and was sentenced to three years probation and a $600 fine in August 2011 after lying to a federal agent about his travel plans. His lenient sentence was the result of U.S. District Court Judge [[Mary H. Murguia]] not finding sufficient evidence to conclude that he planned to join a terrorist organization.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/may/05/elton-simpson-fbi-had-monitored-texas-gunman-since-2006|title=Texas shooting: FBI had monitored gunman Elton Simpson since 2006|work=the Guardian}}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/garland-texas-police-are-looking-into-whether-shooting-was-a-terrorist-attack-2015-5|title=Texas police are looking into whether a shooting at a Muhammad cartoon contest was a terrorist attack|work=Business Insider|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} He was put on the U.S. federal [[No Fly List]]. He had previously intended to travel with others to [[Syria]] to fight with ISIL, though his accomplices were arrested during simultaneous FBI raids in [[San Diego]] and [[Minneapolis]].{{cite web|url=https://gma.yahoo.com/garland-shooting-suspects-private-messages-noose-tightening-121646543--abc-news-topstories.html|title=Garland Shooting Suspect's Private Messages: 'The Noose Is Tightening'|work=Yahoo! News GMA|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} Authorities had already opened an investigation of Simpson at the time of the attack. He also interacted with [[Junaid Hussain]], a British-born hacker and member of ISIL, and [[Mujahid Miski]], an [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)|Al-Shabaab]] recruiter and propagandist of Muslim extremism from [[Minnesota]], via Twitter through "secure communication". Hussain was also the founder of a pro-ISIL hacker group called "CyberCaliphate", which was responsible for a cyber-attack on the [[United States Central Command]]'s Twitter account in January 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/did-isis-instruct-texas-gunmen-elton-simpson-nadir-soofi-to-attack-art-contest|title=Did ISIS instruct Texas gunmen to attack?|work=CBS News|date=May 6, 2015|accessdate=May 6, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/may/6/white-house-raises-lone-wolf-scenario-texas-attack/|title=Muhammad cartoon contest shooting consistent with 'lone wolf' attack, White House says|work=Washington Times|date=May 6, 2015|accessdate=May 7, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ktvq.com/story/28996661/isis-jihadi-linked-to-garland-attack-has-long-history-as-hacker |title=ISIS jihadi linked to Garland attack has long history as hacker |work=KTVQ |date=May 7, 2015 |accessdate=May 7, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518101903/http://www.ktvq.com/story/28996661/isis-jihadi-linked-to-garland-attack-has-long-history-as-hacker |archivedate=May 18, 2015 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/07/politics/fbi-warning-elton-simpson-cartoon-event-attack/|title=Texas attacker had private conversations with known terrorists|work=CNN Politics|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=May 24, 2015}} A week prior to the attack, Simpson mentioned the "First Annual Muhammad Art Exhibit and Contest" event in a tweet sent to what is believed to be Hassan's Twitter account. Simpson then asked, "When will they ever learn?", and Hassan responded: "The brothers from [[Charlie Hebdo shooting|the ''Charlie Hebdo'' attack]] did their part. It's time for brothers in the #US to do their part." Investigators believe Hussain and Hassan encouraged Simpson to commit an attack on U.S. soil, but also that Simpson assembled the attack plan and targeted the art exhibit on his own accord. Simpson was identified as the same user who posted a [[Tweet (Twitter)|tweet]] with the [[hashtag]] #texasattack: "May [[Allah]] accept us as [[mujahideen]]." The profile photo on #texasattack was of the late American [[Salafi]] imam [[Anwar al-Awlaki]], who had repeatedly called for violence against cartoonists who insulted the Muslim prophet Muhammad prior to being killed in a U.S. drone strike in 2011 in Yemen.[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/05/us/garland-texas-shooting-muhammad-cartoons.html?_r=0 New York Times: "Gunman in Texas Shooting Was F.B.I. Suspect in Jihad Inquiry," By MANNY FERNANDEZ, RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and FERNANDA SANTOS], May 4, 2015 Junaid Hussain was identified as the ISIL propagandist whom Simpson recommended his readers to follow in that same tweet. ===Nadir Soofi=== {{Infobox person |name = Nadir Soofi |birth_name = Nadir Hamid Soofi |birth_date = {{circa}} 1981 |birth_place = [[Dallas]], Texas, U.S. |death_date = May 3, 2015 (aged 33 or 34) |death_place = [[Garland, Texas]], U.S. |death_cause = Gunshot wounds |residence = [[Phoenix, Arizona]], U.S. |nationality = American |occupation = Business owner }} Soofi's father, Azam Soofi,{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/father-texas-shooter-nadir-soofi-says-he-was-pushed-attack-329090|title=Father of Texas Shooter Nadir Soofi Says He Was 'Pushed' Into Attack|work=Newsweek|date=May 6, 2015|accessdate=May 15, 2015}} is Pakistani, and his mother, Sharon Soofi, is American. According to his mother, he was born at [[Presbyterian Hospital of Dallas]] and lived in Garland until age three.{{cite web|url=http://thescoopblog.dallasnews.com/2015/05/garland-shooters-mom-says-her-son-died-near-where-he-was-born-gave-no-hint-of-violence.html|publisher=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|author=Weiss, Jeffrey|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015|title=Garland shooter's mom says her son died near where he was born, gave no hint of violence}} The family then moved to [[Plano, Texas]], and then [[Alabama]]. His mother, who was raised [[Catholicism|Catholic]], converted to Islam at the request of his father.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-texas-gunman-20150505-story.html#page=1|title=Texas gunman's mother: 'He just had a normal American upbringing'|work=Los Angeles Times|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} Soofi was also raised as a Muslim by his father. He and his brother moved to [[Pakistan]] with their father and stepmother after their parents were divorced in the 1990s. During his time there, Soofi attended the [[International School of Islamabad]], where he was said by friends to have been popular among his classmates. In 1998, after living in Pakistan for six years,{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/gunmen-plotting-texas-attack-seen-as-quiet-respectful|title=Slain gunmen in Texas attack seen as "quiet," "respectful"|work=CBS News|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} Soofi moved back to the U.S. to live with his mother in [[Utah]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rawstory.com/2015/05/nadir-soofi-texas-gunman-had-happy-childhood-in-pakistan-but-struggled-in-us/|title=Nadir Soofi: Texas gunman had happy childhood in Pakistan but struggled in US|work=Raw Story|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} The two later moved to Phoenix in the mid-2000s.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3069354/Pictured-Texas-gunman-community-college-basketball-star-family-say-brainwashed-heartthrob-roommate-carrying-attack.html|title=Pictured: Texas gunman as a community college basketball star before family say he 'brainwashed' his 'heartthrob' roommate into carrying out attack|work=Daily Mail|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} According to his friends in Pakistan, he had difficulties adjusting to the American culture upon moving to the U.S. He took a [[pre-medical]] course at the [[University of Utah]] starting in the fall semester of 1998, but dropped out in the summer of 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/crime/headlines/20150504-2-garland-shooters-lives-twined-to-tragic-end.ece|title=2 Garland shooters’ lives twined to tragic end|work=The Dallas Morning News|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} At one point, he also owned Cleopatra Bistro Pizza, a pizza and hot wings eatery that served [[halal]] food, though the business struggled and eventually closed down five months prior to the attack. Soofi was arrested and charged for more than twenty minor offenses, most of them traffic violations.{{cite web|url=http://www.sltrib.com/news/2479109-155/texas-gunman-attended-university-of-utah|title=Texas gunman attended U. of U. from '98 to '03|work=The Salt Lake Tribune|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 7, 2015}} In June 2001, when he was twenty, he pleaded guilty to possession of alcohol by a minor. In March 2002, he pleaded guilty to alcohol-related reckless driving, followed by another guilty plea in June 2002 for driving on a suspended license. In 2003, he was charged for distributing a controlled substance and possessing drug paraphernalia, although the case was later dismissed. That same year in July, Soofi pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor assault charge. The case was also dismissed.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/accused-texas-gunman-former-target-fbi-terror-probe-063755313.html|title=Doubts raised about Islamic State's claim in Texas attack|work=Yahoo! News|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} He was survived by his parents and an eight-year-old son from a failed marriage.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/elton-simpson-nadir-soofi-named-gunmen-texas-attack-n353231|title=Elton Simpson and Nadir Soofi Named as Gunmen in Texas Attack|work=NBC News|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/news/texas/article/The-Latest-on-Texas-attack-FBI-searches-2nd-6240858.php |title=The Latest on prophet cartoon case: 1 man's mom speaks out |work=seattlepi |date=May 4, 2015 |accessdate=May 4, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518050940/http://www.seattlepi.com/news/texas/article/The-Latest-on-Texas-attack-FBI-searches-2nd-6240858.php |archivedate=May 18, 2015 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/draw-muhammad-contest-shooting-grandmother-calls-nadir-soofi-good-boy-n353636|title='Draw Muhammad' Contest Shooting: Grandmother Calls Nadir Soofi 'a Good Boy'|work=NBC News|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=June 10, 2015}} After the attack, his mother said her son was "brainwashed" by Simpson, claims that were echoed by his father and maternal grandmother, and that she did not blame police for killing her son.{{cite web|url=http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2015/05/05/afp-isis-claims-responsibility-for-garland-attack/|title=ISIS Claims Responsibility For Garland Attack|work=cbslocal.com|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} ===Abdul Malik Abdul Kareem=== {{Infobox person |name = Abdul Kareem |birth_name = Decarus Lowell Thomas |alias = Abdul Malik Abdul Kareem |birth_date = {{circa}} 1972 (age 42 or 43) |birth_place = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], U.S. |nationality = American |occupation = }} Abdul Kareem was born and raised in [[Philadelphia]] as Decarus Lowell Thomas. In 2013, he changed his name to Abdul Malik Abdul Kareem and converted to Islam. He occasionally attended the Islamic Community Center of Phoenix since at least 2011 and cleaned carpets there. Kareem had a criminal record in Arizona, including two aggravated drunken driving convictions and an aggravated assault charge in 1997. In the latter incident, a woman told police that he pointed a gun in her direction; Abdul Kareem claimed he instead took the weapon away from his brother during an argument and wasn't pointing it at anyone.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2015/06/16/indictment-phoenix-area-man-helped-plan-provided-guns-for-texas-cartoon-contest/|title=Man allegedly helped plan Texas cartoon contest shooting|work=FOX News|date=June 17, 2015|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} He had been arrested a total of eleven times between 1991 and 2004, and also served jail time twice.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc15.com/news/region-phoenix-metro/central-phoenix/abdul-malik-abdul-kareem-update-trial-set-for-phoenix-man-tied-to-texas-shooting|title=Abdul Malik Abdul Kareem update: Trial set for Phoenix man tied to Texas shooting|work=ABC 15|date=July 2, 2015|accessdate=August 9, 2015}} Following the attack, he lied to FBI investigators several times and said he was not asked by Simpson or Soofi to directly participate in the attack. However, according to a confidential informant, Kareem was indeed planning on participating with them and had been angry at the informant for not selling him [[suppressor]]s and [[bulletproof vest]]s. He allegedly attempted to fund the attack by feigning injuries inflicted after being struck by a car and then making an insurance claim based on the injuries. Previously, Abdul Kareem was investigated by the FBI in 2012 for having a terrorism training document on his computer and developing a plot to attack the [[Super Bowl XLIX]] game in [[Glendale, Arizona]] with pipe bombs.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/12/26/us/arizona-isis-super-bowl-attack-indictment/|title=Arizona man linked to cartoon contest attack faces new charges|work=CNN|date=December 26, 2015|accessdate=December 31, 2015}} He had also reportedly accessed a list released by ISIL, which contained the names and addresses of U.S. service members.{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/local-news/20151225-charge-links-garland-shooters-trainer-to-isis-list-of-u.s.-troops.ece|title=Charge links Garland shooters’ trainer to ISIS list of U.S. troops|work=Dallas Morning News|date=December 25, 2015|accessdate=December 31, 2015}} He was arrested on June 11 and charged with "conspiracy, making false statements and interstate transportation of firearms with intent to commit a felony." According to an indictment, Kareem practiced shooting with Simpson and Soofi between January and May in Phoenix. According to CNN, the firearms were all bought legally.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/05/us/garland-texas-prophet-mohammed-contest-shooting|title=ISIS claims responsibility for Texas shooting but offers no proof|work=CNN|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 19, 2015}} His trial was initially set for August 4, but it was later rescheduled for October 6. On December 21, Abdul Kareem was also charged with conspiring to provide support to ISIL and attempting to attack the Super Bowl XLIX game. On March 17, 2016, Kareem was found guilty of conspiring with terrorists for helping the attack's perpetrators plan to carry it out.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/18/us/garland-texas-attack-abdul-malik-abdul-kareem.html?_r=0 | title=Guilty Verdict for Aiding in Attack on Anti-Islam Cartoon Event in Texas | work=New York Times | date=17 March 2016 | accessdate=17 March 2016 | author=Santos, Fernanda}} ==ISIL claim of responsibility== In addition to the gunman's tweet pledging allegiance to ISIL, the jihadist group claimed responsibility for the attack, stating on its Al Bayan radio station that "two soldiers of the Caliphate executed an attack on an art exhibit in Garland, Texas.... This exhibit was portraying negative pictures of the Prophet Mohammed." It marked the first time ISIL took credit for an attack in the mainland U.S. ISIL promised to launch further attacks in the future.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/claims-responsibility-texas-cartoon-attack-090629845.html|title=Islamic State claims responsibility for Texas cartoon attack|work=Yahoo! News|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} There was initially no evidence that ISIL had contact with the perpetrators, and law enforcement groups continued to investigate a possible link.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/05/us/garland-texas-prophet-mohammed-contest-shooting/index.html|title=ISIS claims responsibility for Texas shooting, threatens more attacks|work=CNN|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} Some counterterrorism experts expressed doubts on the legitimacy of those claims, noting that ISIL has in the past claimed responsibility for attacks they actually had no involvement in. One U.S. official said the attack was "certainly more than just inspiration" by ISIL. A law enforcement official said the attack did "not appear to be a clear-cut case of a lone wolf, nor a pure case of someone directed by others to act"; instead, "it appears to be something in between the two extremes". According to Defense Secretary [[Ashton Carter]], the shooting was inspired, but not directed, by ISIL.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/11590852/Texas-attack-inspired-but-not-directed-by-Islamic-State-Pentagon-chief.html|title=Texas attack inspired but not directed by Islamic State: Pentagon chief|agency=Agence France-Presse|date=May 7, 2015}}[http://www.defense.gov/News/News-Transcripts/Transcript-View/Article/607048/department-of-defense-press-briefing-by-secretary-ash-carter-and-general-martin Department of Defense Press Briefing by Secretary Ash Carter and General Martin E. Dempsey in the Pentagon Briefing Room], [[United States Department of Defense]] (May 7, 2015). In August 2015, [[Centcom]] announced that it had killed [[Junaid Hussain]] in a drone strike in Syria, due to his influence in motivating [[Lone wolf (terrorism)|lone wolf]]-style attacks.{{cite web|url=http://www.defense.gov/News-Article-View/Article/615305/iraq-progresses-in-isil-fight-key-extremist-confirmed-dead|title=Iraq Progresses in ISIL Fight, Key Extremist Confirmed Dead|work=U.S. Department of Defense|date=August 28, 2015|accessdate=September 1, 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/28/world/middleeast/junaid-hussain-islamic-state-recruiter-killed.html|title=Junaid Hussain, ISIS Recruiter, Reported Killed in Airstrike|work=The New York Times|date=August 27, 2015|accessdate=September 1, 2015}} U.S. officials reportedly had a strong desire to assassinate Hussain, listing him as the third-highest ISIL target on the Pentagon's "[[kill list]]" behind [[Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi]] and [[Mohammed Emwazi]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/news/uk_news/article1588418.ece|title=British hacker is No 3 on Pentagon 'kill list'|work=The Sunday Times|date=August 2, 2015|accessdate=September 1, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://europe.newsweek.com/junaid-hussain-how-boy-birmingham-became-isiss-leading-hacker-332108|title=Junaid Hussain: How a Boy From Birmingham Became ISIS's Leading Hacker|date=August 27, 2015|work=Newsweek|accessdate=September 1, 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/13/isis-hacking-division-releases-details-of-1400-americans-and-urges-attacks|title=Isis 'hacking division' releases details of 1,400 Americans and urges attacks|author=Michael Safi|work=The Guardian|date=August 12, 2015|accessdate=September 1, 2015}} In December 2017, a Florida Jewish American [[internet troll]], [[Joshua Ryne Goldberg]], was convicted of planning the bombing of a 2015 [[September 11 attacks|9/11]] memorial event in [[Kansas City]].{{Cite news|url=http://claytodayonline.com/stories/clay-county-man-enters-guilty-plea-to-bomb-charge,9711|title=Clay County man enters guilty plea to bomb charge|work=Clay Today|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en}} In his communications with an FBI informant, Goldberg claimed credit for inspiring the Garland attack. Goldberg's fake Twitter persona using the name "Australi Witness" had posted a map of the Curtis Culwell Center and urged any in the area to attack "with your weapons, bombs, or knives". News reports about Goldberg's online persona calling for the Garland attack first brought Goldberg to the attention of the FBI. The FBI also found that Elton Simpson retweeted a message from Goldberg's Twitter handle on the morning of the attack.{{Cite news|url = http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/national/aussie-jihadi-behind-911-memorial-threat-is-actually-a-jewish-american-internet-troll/story-fni0xqrc-1227524374297|title = ‘Aussie jihadi’ behind 9/11 memorial threat is actually a Jewish-American internet troll|date = September 13, 2015|accessdate = September 13, 2015|publisher = The Daily Telegraph}}{{Cite news|url = http://www.haaretz.com/news/world/1.675698|title = Australian Online ISIS Jihadist Turns Out to Be Florida Jew|date = September 13, 2015|accessdate = September 13, 2015|publisher = Haaretz}}{{Cite news|url = http://www.timesofisrael.com/florida-jew-arrested-for-posing-as-online-jihadist-encouraging-terrorism/|title = Florida Jew arrested for posing as online jihadist, encouraging terrorism|date = September 13, 2015|accessdate = September 13, 2015|publisher = Times of Israel}}{{cite web|url = http://www.justice.gov/usao-mdfl/file/769491/download|title = United States v. JOSHUA RYNE GOLDBERG Criminal Complaint|accessdate = September 13, 2015|publisher = United States Department of Justice}} ==Reactions and aftermath== Following the attack, [[Governor of Texas|Texas Governor]] [[Greg Abbott]] released a statement, calling the attack "senseless" and promising there was an investigation underway. He also issued his gratitude to the Garland police officers for their swift action against the assailants. [[United States Secretary of Homeland Security|U.S. Secretary of Homeland Security]] [[Jeh Johnson]] said
[The attack] serves as a reminder that free and protected speech, no matter how offensive to some, never justifies violence of any sort. This attack also underscores the importance of close collaboration between federal, state and local authorities in our Nation's homeland security efforts, as well as public awareness and vigilance.
Johnson urged American citizens to not "misdirect" their anger at Muslims. Texas Republican Senator [[John Cornyn]] said the contest was an expression of free speech.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyjournal.net/view/story/14ac9186cb9447aea63b8a4f974980ef/US--Prophet-Cartoon-Contest-Shooting-The-Latest |title=Cornyn: Contest an expression of Free Speech |work=The Daily Journal |accessdate=May 6, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530142403/http://www.dailyjournal.net/view/story/14ac9186cb9447aea63b8a4f974980ef/US--Prophet-Cartoon-Contest-Shooting-The-Latest |archivedate=May 30, 2015 }} [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|U.N. Secretary-General]] [[Ban Ki-moon]] also condemned the attack in a statement.{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/news/texas/article/The-Latest-on-Texas-attack-FBI-searches-2nd-6240858.php |title=The Latest on prophet cartoon case: SWAT helped kill gunmen |work=Chron |date=May 4, 2015 |accessdate=May 4, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505030701/http://www.chron.com/news/texas/article/The-Latest-on-Texas-attack-FBI-searches-2nd-6240858.php |archivedate=May 5, 2015 }} Muslim organizations also reacted to the attack. The [[Council on American–Islamic Relations]] issued a statement condemning the attack and saying, "Bigoted speech can never be an excuse for violence." Dr. Nasim Rehmatullah, National Vice President of the U.S. chapter of the [[Ahmadiyya|Ahmadiyya Muslim Community]], also said in a statement:
Violence is never an acceptable response to hate speech, no matter how inflammatory and uncivilized that speech is. While we do not yet know what motivated these shooters, we urge calm and defer to local, state, and federal authorities to peaceably and justly resolve this.
Following the attack, ISIL supporters expressed their support online with postings on ISIL-affiliated websites.MAAMOUN YOUSSEF, [https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2015/05/05/is-claims-responsibility-for-texas-cartoon-attack U.S. News & World Report: "Islamic State Says Cartoon Attack Our Work Islamic State group claims responsibility for Texas attack targeting cartoon contest center"], usnews.com, May 5, 2015. Bosch Fawstin, the winner of the cartoon contest, has received numerous death threats.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/muhammad-cartoon-contest-winner-retreats-into-hiding-1430852911|title=Muhammad Cartoon Contest Winner Retreats Into Hiding|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|date=May 5, 2015|author=Nathan Koppel}} The [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] plans to discuss the incident in its 2016 report on hate in the United States.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/05/05/us-usa-shooting-texas-cartoonist-idUSKBN0NP1ZS20150505|title=Mohammad cartoonist says U.S. police killing of two gunmen 'justice'|date=May 5, 2015|work=Reuters|author1=Letitia Stein|author2=Colleen Jenkins}} In the wake of the attack, the Garland Independent School District announced it would begin reviewing its policy for hosting events at the Curtis Culwell Center.{{cite web|url=http://www.khou.com/story/news/local/texas/2015/05/05/garland-isd-to-review-policies-for-booking-event-centers/26911501|title=Garland ISD to review policies for booking event centers|work=KHOU|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 6, 2015}} On May 29, 2015, protesters staging a "Freedom of Speech" rally outside of the [[Islamic Community Center of Phoenix]], the same mosque where Simpson and Soofi had attended, were met with counter-protests. [[Jon Ritzheimer]], a former U.S. Marine, organized the protest to take place during Friday evening prayers as a "response to the recent attacks in Texas."{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/29/us/mohammed-cartoon-contest/|title=Mohammed cartoon contest: Protest held outside Phoenix mosque|date=May 30, 2015|work=CNN|author=Sara Sidner|author2=Ed Payne}} On June 2, 2015, [[Boston]] police killed a [[Roslindale]] man armed with a military-style knife after the man charged at the officers.{{cite news|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/news_opinion/local_coverage/2015/06/roslindale_man_killed_in_showdown_with_anti_terror_task_force|title=Roslindale man killed in showdown with anti-terror task force|date=June 2, 2015|accessdate=June 3, 2015|work=The Boston Herald|author=Owen Boss|author2= Antonio Planas|author3=O'Ryan Johnson|author4= Bob McGovern}} The man had [[2015 Boston beheading plot|planned to assassinate Geller]] because of the contest, but became impatient and decided to target local police instead.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/03/us/boston-police-shooting/index.html|title=Boston shooting: Suspect plotted to behead Pamela Geller, sources say|work=CNN|date=June 3, 2015|accessdate=June 3, 2015}} In an interview with CNN, Geller denied that the event was intentionally provocative, criticized the media for not defending the First Amendment, and pointed out that other religions have been similarly offended but do not react violently.{{cite web|url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2015/05/04/pamela_geller_vs_cnn_host_on_mohammed_cartoon_contest_shooting_were_abridging_our_freedoms_so_as_not_to_offend_savages.html|title=Pamela Geller vs. CNN Host on Mohammed Cartoon Contest Shooting: "We're Abridging Our Freedoms So As Not To Offend Savages"|work=Real Clear Politics|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 30, 2015}} Geller later told [[CNN]] that the shooting would not stop her and the AFDI from organizing similar events in the future. She said regarding the attack, "Freedom of speech is under violent assault here."{{cite web|url=http://www.wfaa.com/story/news/local/dallas-county/2015/05/04/garland-shooting-stirs-debate-about-art-gathering/26896663|title=Garland shooting stirs debate about cartoon contest|work=WFAA|date=May 4, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} She also said that the shooting showed how "needed our event really was."{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/Garland-Officer-Saved-Lives-at-Prophet-Muhammad-Art-Contest-Police-Say-302436191.html|title=Garland Officer Saved Lives at Muhammad Art Contest, Police Say|work=NBC DFW|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=May 5, 2015}} The ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' reported on August 1 that Soofi, despite his long rap sheet, purchased a [[9mm]] gun in 2010 at Lone Wolf Trading Co., one of the private companies encouraged by the [[Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives]] (ATF) to sell weapons to persons who normally would not be legally allowed such purchases, an action that would later become the [[ATF gunwalking scandal]]. The ''Tribune'' wrote that Soofi's purchase was initially put on a seven-day hold but that "for reasons that remain unclear, the hold was lifted after 24 hours, and Soofi got the 9-millimeter." The day after the attack, the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Department of Justice]] sent an urgent firearms disposition request to Lone Wolf Trading Co. As of the date of the ''Tribune''{{'}}s report, the FBI has not released any details of the guns used by Simpson and Soofi.{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/la-na-garland-gun-20150801-story.html#page=1|title=Garland, Texas, shooter bought gun in 2010 during Fast and Furious|work=The Chicago Tribune|date=August 1, 2015|accessdate=August 9, 2015}} === Lawsuit against the FBI === The injured security guard, Bruce Joiner, filed a lawsuit in Oct 2017 against the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] and [[United States Department of Justice|DOJ]]. His suit argues the bureau "solicited, encouraged, directed and aided members of ISIS in planning and carrying out the May 3 attack," and is asking for just over $8 million damages. Evidence submitted to court confirm that an FBI undercover agent, dressed in middle eastern attire, followed the attackers to the attack site. When he saw the attack underway he attempted to flee and was nearly killed himself by police at the scene.[http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/victim-of-draw-muhammad-isis-inspired-terror-attack-sues-fbi-accuses-james-comey-of-cover-up/article/2636321 Lawsuit accuses FBI of not stopping Garland Attack] The lawsuit alleges that the FBI knew about the attack, and allowed it to proceed, so that their undercover agent can earn "street cred" with ISIS directly. The suit asks for damages because the FBI knew about the attack but made no effort to stop it, or to warn the intended victims that danger was imminent.[http://freebeacon.com/national-security/fbi-doj-argue-dismissal-suit-garland-texas-attack/ FBI attempts to dismiss lawsuit] ==Support and criticism of event== {{POV section|date=May 2016}} ===Support for Geller and AFDI=== In an interview with [[Fox News]] Channel's ''[[The Kelly File]]'', [[UCLA]] School of Law professor [[Eugene Volokh]] said
[T]his kind of discussion has value in debate about Islam and about the role of Islam and about the reaction of some Muslims, fortunately only a small portion of Muslims do these kinds of things. But beyond that it has value as a reaffirmation of our free speech rights. It has value as an act of defiance. It has value as people saying: look, we are not going to be shut up. When you tell us that we cannot draw pictures of Mohammed, when you tell us we cannot say these things or else you'll kill us, that just means that we're going to do it again and again to show that you cannot threaten Americans into submission.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2015/05/07/eugene-volokh-interviewed-about-free-speech-by-megyn-kelly/|title=Eugene Volokh interviewed about free speech by Megyn Kelly|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=May 23, 2015|author=Randy Barnett}}
Also on ''The Kelly File'', [[Alan Dershowitz]] said that "critics of Pamela Geller...should realize that while she may have intended to provoke a negative reaction from extreme Islamists, she shares something in common with civil rights leader the Rev. [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]]"{{cite news|url=http://www.newsmax.com/Headline/alan-dershowitz-pamela-geller-like-martin-luther-king/2015/05/07/id/643355/|title=Dershowitz: Geller Critics Should Realize MLK Provoked, Too|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=May 22, 2015|author=Greg Richter}}{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/2015/05/11/pamela_geller_is_a_coward_right_wing_medias_big_lie_and_shocking_mlk_slander/|title=Pamela Geller is a coward: Right-wing media’s big lie and shocking MLK slander|date=May 11, 2015|accessdate=May 30, 2015|author=Musa al-Gharbi|work=Salon}} [[Victor Davis Hanson]] wrote in an article in the ''[[National Review]]'' online magazine that "radical Islam has already cut a huge swathe out of American free speech through more than a decade of death threats." He also wrote that the criticism directed towards Geller for supposedly striking up religious hatred was "scary" and compared Geller to the cartoonists who were killed during the [[Charlie Hebdo shooting|''Charlie Hebdo'' shooting]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/418201/first-and-half-amendment-victor-davis-hanson|title=The First — and a Half — Amendment|date=May 12, 2015|accessdate=May 23, 2015|author=Victor Davis Hanson}} [[Bret Stephens]], [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning columnist for ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', put Geller's speech in the same category as [[Bill Maher]] or the writers of ''[[Charlie Hebdo]]'' — legitimate speech against Islamism — and commented, "I say Islamist because there is a rich history of Muslim depictions of Muhammad." He also added that "those [who] blame Geller for the provocation are [[blaming the victim]] just as those who say rape victims are asking for it." Stephens went on to argue that a "society that rejects the notion of a heckler's veto cannot accept the idea of a murderer's veto..."{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/in-defense-of-pamela-geller-1431386626|title=In Defense of Pamela Geller: A society that rejects the notion of a heckler’s veto cannot accept the idea of a murderer’s veto|work=Wall Street Journal|date=May 11, 2015|author=Bret Stephens|accessdate=June 1, 2015}} [[Rich Lowry]], writing in ''[[Politico]]'', defended Geller's idea that the contest and exhibit's purpose was about freedom of speech:
Respectable opinion can't bear the idea that she has become a symbol of free speech, which once upon a time was — and still is, when convenient — one of the highest values of the media and the left. If Geller were a groundbreaking pornographer like the loathsome Larry Flynt, someone would already be planning a celebratory biopic of her life. If she were a gadfly sticking it to a major Western religion rather than to Islam, she might be considered more socially acceptable.{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2015/05/why-wont-pamela-geller-shut-up-117716.html#ixzz3boU8sLpY|title=Why Won't Pamela Geller Shut Up?|work=Politico|author=Rich Lowery|date=May 6, 2015}}
===Criticism of Geller and AFDI=== On the day after the shooting, [[Donald Trump]], appearing on ''[[Fox & Friends]]'', questioned Geller's motives. He said, "It looks like she's just taunting everybody. What is she doing? Drawing Mohammed and it looks like she's actually taunting people. (...) You know, I'm one that believes in free speech, probably more than she does. But what's the purpose of this?" In response to Trump's remarks, [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] said in his program ''[[The O'Reilly Factor]]'', "Mr. Trump is correct. By setting up a contest and awarding $10,000 for a depiction of the Prophet Mohammed, the American Freedom Defense Initiative spurred a violent attack. (...) Insulting a religion with more than a billion followers does not advance the cause of defeating the fanatical jihadists. It hurts the cause."{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/donald-trump-lambasts-disgusting-pam-geller-for-baiting-muslims-with-draw-the-prophet-contest-in-texas-10226027.html|title=Donald Trump lambasts 'disgusting' Pam Geller for baiting Muslims with 'draw the prophet' contest in Texas|newspaper=The Independent|date=May 5, 2015|author=Jenn Selby|accessdate=May 7, 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.billoreilly.com/b/Defeating-the-Jihad-by-Not-Being-Dumb/250143775297720127.html|title=Defeating the Jihad by Not Being Dumb|newspaper=billoreilly.com|date=May 5, 2015|author=Bill O'Reilly|accessdate=May 7, 2015}} [[Fox News]]' ''[[On the Record w/ Greta Van Susteren|On the Record]]'' host [[Greta Van Susteren]] criticized Geller for putting police officers' lives in danger. She said, "It's one thing for someone to stand up for the First Amendment and put his own you-know-what on the line, but here, those insisting they were defending the First Amendment were knowingly putting officers' lives on the line — the police."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2015/05/06/fox-newss-greta-van-susteren-scolds-pamela-geller/|title=Fox News’s Greta Van Susteren scolds Pamela Geller|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=May 6, 2015|author=Erik Wemple|accessdate=May 7, 2015}} Geller and [[Islamist]] [[Anjem Choudary]] appeared on ''[[Hannity]]'' on Fox News to debate the merits of AFDI's contest. In response to host [[Sean Hannity]]'s question about whether Choudary supported an unverified ISIL [[fatwa]]{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2015/05/06/isis_claims_to_have_71_soldiers_in_15_states_ready_to_kill_pam_geller_and_any_who_defend_her|title=ISIS Claims to Have 71 Soldiers in 15 States Ready to Kill Pam Geller and Any Who Defend Her|last1=Kaufman|first1=Scott Eric|date=May 6, 2015|accessdate=May 30, 2015|website=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]}} and posted on an anonymous message board calling for Geller's death, he replied, "This isn't Mickey Mouse or Donald Duck they were drawing. This is the prophet. This woman wants to have people draw cartoons that insult the prophet knowing full well that carries the death penalty in Islam. So definitely, she's asking people to attack." When Hannity asked whether he thought Geller should die, Choudary said, "She should be tried in a [[sharia]] court, be found guilty, and, of course, she would face capital punishment." After Hannity reminded Choudary that Geller is not a Muslim, he continued, "You can't go down that road, insulting Muslims, and think the Muslims aren't going to retaliate back. I would attack someone if they insult my mother, let alone the prophet who I love 100 times more."{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2015/05/07/you_want_her_to_die_watch_pam_geller_and_anjem_choudary_brawl_on_hannity|title="You Want Her to Die!": Watch Pam Geller and Anjem Choudary Brawl on "Hannity"|last1=Kaufman|first1=Scott Eric|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=May 30, 2015|website=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]}} Garland Mayor Douglas Athas said he wished Geller had not chosen his town for her event and explained, "Her actions put my police officers, my citizens and others at risk. Her program invited an incendiary reaction. She picked my community, which does not support in any shape, passion or form, her ideology. (...) But at the end of the day, we did our jobs, we protected her freedoms and her life".{{cite news|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/crime/headlines/20150505-islamic-state-claims-garland-attack-white-house-says-possible-link-being-investigated.ece|title=Islamic State claims Garland attack; White House says possible link being investigated|newspaper=The Dallas Morning News|date=May 6, 2015|author=Ray Leszcynski, Todd J. Gillman and Michael E. Young|accessdate=May 7, 2015}} In an interview with ''[[The New York Times]]'', the editor of ''[[Charlie Hebdo]]'', Gérard Biard, rejected "attempts by right-wing activists to exploit that attack for their own agendas". He also added, "We have nothing to do with Pamela Geller's work. When Islam or the Prophet Muhammad jump out of the news, we comment on it, we mock it, maybe. But we are not obsessed about it."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/06/world/europe/charlie-hebdo-editor-seeks-to-distance-newspaper-from-anti-islam-causes.html|title=Charlie Hebdo Editor Seeks to Distance Newspaper From Anti-Islam Causes|newspaper=The New York Times|date=May 5, 2015|author=Rick Gladstone}} ==See also== * [[2015 Copenhagen shootings]] * [[Charlie Hebdo shooting|''Charlie Hebdo'' shooting]] * [[Everybody Draw Mohammed Day]] * [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy|''Jyllands-Posten'' Muhammad cartoons controversy]] * [[List of Islamist terrorist attacks]] {{Portal bar|Criminal justice|Dallas – Fort Worth Metroplex|Freedom of speech|Islam|Terrorism}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Garland, Texas}} {{Garland ISD}} {{Depictions of Muhammad|state=autocollapse}} {{Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant}} [[Category:2015 in Texas]] [[Category:2015 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Attacks in the United States in 2015]] [[Category:Crimes in Texas]] [[Category:Defensive gun use]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Muhammad]] [[Category:Failed terrorist attempts in the United States]] [[Category:Freedom of speech in the United States]] [[Category:Garland, Texas]] [[Category:ISIL terrorist incidents in the United States]] [[Category:Islamic terrorism in Texas]] [[Category:Islamic terrorism in the United States]] [[Category:May 2015 crimes]] [[Category:May 2015 events in the United States]] [[Category:People shot dead by law enforcement officers in the United States|+Curtis]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents in Texas]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents in the United States in 2015]] [[Category:Garland Independent School District]]

revision.comment: Typo fixing, replaced: On May 1927 → In May 1927 using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox political party |name = Czechoslovak Social Democratic Workers Party in the Republic of Austria |native_name = Československá sociálně demokratická strana dělnická v republice Rakoúské |chairman = Lesak (1925), W. Filar (1928), Čeněk Sahanek (1931) |founded = {{Start date|1919|12|07}} |international = [[Labour and Socialist International]] |newspaper = ''Vídeňské dělnické listy'' |ideology = [[Social democracy]] |country = Austria |membership_year = 1928 |membership = 14,200 |headquarters = Margaretenplatz 7, [[Vienna]] V<ref name="kon"/> }} The '''Czechoslovak Social Democratic Workers Party in the Republic of Austria''' ({{lang-cs|Československá sociálně demokratická strana dělnická v republice Rakoúské}}) was a [[political party]] in [[Austria]], working amongst the [[Czechs|Czech]] minority.<ref name="kow"/> The party was founded on December 7, 1919, as the Vienna branch of the [[Czech Social Democratic Party|Czechoslovak Social Democratic Workers Party]] separated itself from the party centre in [[Prague]] (with the break-up of the [[Austro-Hungarian empire]] the party branches in Vienna and Prague were now parts of two different states).<ref name="wien">Brousek, Karl M. ''[https://books.google.com/books?hl=sv&id=U1yMS8ozHOoC Wien und seine Tschechen: Integration und Assimilation einer Minderheit im 20. Jahrhundert]''. Schriftenreihe des Österreichischen Ost- und Südosteuropa-Instituts, Bd. 7. München: Oldenbourg, 1980. pp. 74-75</ref> The party worked closely together with the [[Social Democratic Workers Party of Austria]] (SDAPÖ), and cooperated with the Austrian Social Democrats on all political issues. The party contested parliamentary elections on joint lists together with SDAPÖ.<ref name="kow"/>
==History== The first, and constituent, party congress was held in 1921. The congress adopted a party programme, which included demands such as the right to education in mother language, the unification of the Vienna urban and rural areas into a single electoral constituency, judicial reform, lowering the voting age to 18 years, full press freedom and direct popular intervention in the legislative. Most of the social demands of the party were similar to those raised by SDAPÖ.<ref name="wien"/>
In May 1927 the party congress adopted a new party programme, following the lines of the SDAPÖ ''[[Linzer Programm|Linz Programme]]''.<ref name="kow"/>
The party was banned in February 1934.<ref name="kow"/> The party then began to operate as an underground organization. Publications were printed in neighbouring [[Czechoslovakia]], and smuggled into Austria.<ref>Brousek, Karl M. ''[https://books.google.com/books?hl=sv&id=U1yMS8ozHOoC Wien und seine Tschechen: Integration und Assimilation einer Minderheit im 20. Jahrhundert]''. Schriftenreihe des Österreichischen Ost- und Südosteuropa-Instituts, Bd. 7. München: Oldenbourg, 1980. p. 89</ref>
==Organization== The party was organized on the principle of individual membership.<ref>Kowalski, Werner. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=OhqESAAACAAJ Geschichte der sozialistischen arbeiter-internationale: 1923 - 1940]''. Berlin: Dt. Verl. d. Wissenschaften, 1985. p. 313</ref> As of 1928, the party claimed a membership of around 14,200, out of whom 3,700 were women.<ref name="kon">[[Labour and Socialist International]]. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=bqElQQAACAAJ Kongress-Protokolle der Sozialistischen Arbeiter-Internationale - B. 3.1 Brüssel 1928]''. Glashütten im Taunus: D. Auvermann, 1974. p. IV. 98</ref> The highest organ of the party was the party congress, held every two years. The congress elected a Party Presidium and Secretariat. The activists of the party were active in the Austrian [[trade union]] movement.<ref name="kow">Kowalski, Werner. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=OhqESAAACAAJ Geschichte der sozialistischen arbeiter-internationale: 1923 - 1940]''. Berlin: Dt. Verl. d. Wissenschaften, 1985. p. 320</ref> The youth wing of the party had, as of 1928, 2,825 members.<ref name="kon"/> In close connection to the party was the educational association, ''Máj'', the Workers Gymnastics Union (DTJ) and cycling clubs. There was also a Czech section of the ''[[Republikanischer Schutzbund]]'', connected to the party.<ref name="wien"/>
The party had offices almost all of the [[Districts of Austria|districts of the country]]. These offices also served as offices for the district branches of the youth and women's wings of the party.<ref name="wien"/>
==Leadership== As of 1925, Lesak was Chairman of the Party Presidium. In 1928 he had been replaced by W. Filar and in 1931 by Čeněk Sahanek.<ref name="kow"/> Other prominent leaders of the party included the parliamentarian František Dvořák, Antonín Machát (municipal councillor on behalf of the Czech minority in Vienna during the [[Second World War]]), František Strnad, Bedřich Čepelka and Josef Petrů.<ref name="wien"/>
As of 1928, the Party Presidium consisted of Filar (chairman), Drahozal, Kopecká, Skranc, Zedniček, Čižek, Strnad, Skřivan (secretary), Adámek, Hajn, Pechowá and Kohl.<ref name="kon"/>
==Press== The central organ of the party was ''Vídeňské dělnické listy'' ('Viennoise Workers' Paper').<ref name="kow"/>
==International affiliation== The party was affiliated to the [[Labour and Socialist International]] between 1923 and 1940.<ref name="kow"/> Alois Wawrousek represented the party in the Executive of the Labour and Socialist International between August 1925 to 1937.<ref>Kowalski, Werner. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=OhqESAAACAAJ Geschichte der sozialistischen arbeiter-internationale: 1923 - 1940]''. Berlin: Dt. Verl. d. Wissenschaften, 1985. p. 283</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{About|Armenian political party established in 2012 by the merger of [[Democratic Liberal Party of Armenia]] established in 1991 and dissolved on 3 June 2012 and [[Armenakan-Democratic Liberal Party]] established in 2009 and dissolved on 3 June 2012|Armenian pan-Diaspora party established as Armenakan Party in 1885 and reformed as Armenian Democratic Liberal Party (ADL) in 1921|Armenian Democratic Liberal Party}} {{Infobox Political party |country = Armenia | name = Democratic Liberal Party (Armenia) |native_name = Ռամկավար Ազատական Կուսակցություն (Հայաստան) |logo = |leader = [[Hakob Avetikyan]] |president = |chairperson = |spokesperson = |leader1_name = |leader2_name = |leader3_name = |foundation = 3 June 2012 |headquarters = [[Yerevan]] |newspaper = |youth_wing = |membership_year= |membership = |ideology = [[Liberalism]]
[[Social democracy]]
[[Pro-Europeanism]]
[[Third Way]] |national = |international = |europarl = |colors = yellow |colorcode = Yellow |website = ''None'' |footnotes = }} '''Democratic Liberal Party (Armenia)''' (in [[Armenian language|Armenian]] Ռամկավար Ազատական Կուսակցություն (Հայաստան) pronounced Ramgavar Azatakan Kusaktsutyun (Hayastan) ) is a new political party formed on 3 June 2012 in [[Armenia]].[http://news.am/arm/news/108034.html Կազմավորվել է նոր կուսակցություն՝ Ռամկավար ազատական կուսակցություն (Հայաստան)] (in Armenian) On December 1, 2011, [[Democratic Liberal Party of Armenia]] and [[Armenakan-Democratic Liberal Party]] had signed an initial agreement for launching a unification process between the two parties. The agreement materialized in the organization of general assemblies by the two formation to approve on unification moves. On 3 June 2012, a joint general constituting assembly was held and union and official declaration of the new party made. Twenty five members were elected as the party's pan-republican Central Committee with Hakob Avetikyan being elected as the general secretary of the party.[http://www.tert.am/am/news/2012/06/05/hrak/ tert.com: Միավորված ռամկավար ազատական կուսակցություն–Հայաստանը խոստանում է առավել ակտիվ լինել] (in Armenian) The new party Democratic Liberal Party (Armenia) is made up of the result of the merger of two existing (and initially rival) liberal democratic parties: *'''[[Democratic Liberal Party of Armenia]]''' (in [[Armenian language|Armenian]] Հայաստանի Ռամկավար Ազատական Կուսակցություն (ՀՌԱԿ) ). The party had been established in July 1991 in Armenia after the independence of the new republic. The laws governing establishment of parties in the newly established republic had stipulations regarding political activities by Diasporan political organizations with head offices outside the republic as was the case of the historical ADL, thus the decision to form a distinct Republic of Armenia party as distinct from the pan-Diasporan historical [[Armenian Democratic Liberal Party]] (ADL) (in [[Armenian language|Armenian]] Ռամկավար Ազատական Կուսակցութիւն (ՌԱԿ) ), although the two parties mostly remained allies throughout the period 1991 until 2012, the date of dissolving of the party. *'''[[Armenakan-Democratic Liberal Party]]''' (in [[Armenian language|Armenian]] Արմենական -Ռամկավար Ազատական Կուսակցություն ) was established in 2009 as a pan-Armenian and pan-Diasporan political party with head office in Armenia, as a splinter group from the historical Armenian Democratic Liberal Party, as a result of deep internal divisions in the party. Armenakan-Democratic Liberal Party had also taken control of some Diapsoran ADL party organs in the Diaspora. The party was considered as a rival grouping to ADL throughout its existence 2009 until the dissolution of the party in 2012. The two parties declared in their last respective general assemblies held the decision to liquidate their parties and join in forces in the new party. They also declared in their joint meeting held at the Tekeyan Center in [[Yerevan]] that the Democratic Liberal Party (Armenia) is the rightful historic continuation of the two earlier parties. The Democratic Liberal Party (Armenia) also made friendly declarations toward the historical '''[[Armenian Democratic Liberal Party]]''' (ADL) in the Diaspora for relationship between the two for very close cooperation in the interest of forming a possible global union in the future. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Armenian political parties}} [[Category:2012 establishments in Armenia]] [[Category:Armenian Democratic Liberal Party]] [[Category:Liberal parties in Armenia]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2012]] [[Category:Political parties in Armenia]] [[Category:Pro-European political parties]] [[Category:Social democratic parties in Armenia]]
