{{Infobox political party | colorcode = | name = League Against Usury | native_name = Liga contra Cametei
Liga împotriva Cametei |logo = Simple crossed circle.svg | president = Eftimie Antonescu | founder = | foundation = August 17, 1929 | dissolution = 1932 | split = | successor = | headquarters = Carol Street 62, [[Bucharest]]''București: Ghid oficial cu 20 hărți pentru orientare'', p. 64. Bucharest: Imprimeria Fundației Culturale Regale, 1934. {{OCLC|163817859}} | ideology = [[Single-issue politics|Single-issue]]
[[Big tent]]
[[Agrarianism]]
[[Producerism]]
[[Economic antisemitism]]
[[Fascism]] (minority) | position = [[Center-left]] to [[far-right]] | newspaper = ''Jos Camăta''
''Desrobirea'' | colours = | slogan = ''Dobânda este un furt ce nu trebuie plătit''
("Interest is theft that we should not cover") | country = Romania }} The '''League Against Usury''' ({{lang-ro|Liga contra Cametei}}, LCC, or ''Liga împotriva Cametei'') was a [[Single-issue politics|single-issue]], mainly [[Agrarianism|agrarian]], political party in [[Romania]]. Formed as a political answer to the [[Great Depression]], it involved itself in the fight against "[[usury]]" (or [[predatory lending]]), bringing together politicians on all sides of the political spectrum. Its prominent backers and activists included leftists such as [[Nicolae L. Lupu]] and [[Ion D. Isac]], independents such as [[Pantelimon Erhan]], [[Stefan Frecôt]], [[George Tutoveanu]] and [[Eraclie Sterian]], and some affiliates of the interwar far-right. The LCC channeled protest votes, and competed in this with fascist movements such as the [[Iron Guard]], ambiguously supporting [[economic antisemitism]]. Although perceived as an upsetting contender, the LCC effectively seconded the [[Democratic Peasants' Party–Stere]]. Under its auspices, it managed to obtain one seat in the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Assembly]] in the [[Romanian general election, 1931|election of June 1931]]. The League's fiscal proposals were embraced by the government of [[Nicolae Iorga]], which also drew in former LCC cadres, while other activists left the League to openly embrace fascism. After involving itself in support of continued [[debt relief]] policies, and failing to win any seats in later elections, the LCC finally dissolved itself in late 1932. ==History== ===Creation=== The LCC was created by the jurist Eftimie "Volică" Antonescu with support from various politicians and journalists. Its constitutive congress was held at Antonescu's home in [[Bucharest]] on Saturday, August 17, 1929."Liga contra cametei", in ''[[Adevărul]]'', August 18, 1929, p. 2 According to one account, the movement may have had roots that predated the Great Depression: a League of the same name (later LCC chapter) was reportedly formed in 1928 by the [[Gorj County]] landowner Alexandru A. Magherescu.''Politics and Political Parties...'', p. 477 Voted in as LCC president, Antonescu had first stirred controversy in 1918, when he acted as a prosecutor selectively investigating wartime abuse.[[Alexandru Marghiloman]], ''Note politice. Vol. 3. 1917–1918'', pp. 309, 412. Bucharest: Editura Institutului de Arte Grafice Eminescu, 1927 His career in politics saw him crossing the floor: he had been a member of the [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative]] and [[Romanian National Party|National Parties]],Moldovan, pp. 129, 259, 282 and afterwards defected to the [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]]. Elected for the [[Senate of Romania|Senate]] seat in Gorj, he had criticized the governing [[National Peasants' Party]] for its handling of the Depression, and also for its passage of multiple and conflicting laws.Roșca & Vlad, pp. 77, 80 The LCC's generic goal was the fight against "usury", structured into three lesser objectives: phasing out interest rates, canceling [[foreclosure]]s, and auditing the "usurers".Ioan Scurtu (ed.), ''Enciclopedia partidelor politice din România, 1859-2003'', p. 155. Bucharest: Editura Meronia, 2003. {{ISBN|973-8200-54-7}} In one of it manifestos, the LCC demanded quick [[Economic interventionism|state intervention]] and the reevaluation of interest at 1%;Clapa, p. 7 according to the peasants' own claims, interest rates could climb as high as 40% or even 100% in 1930."Où va la Roumanie?", p. 17 That year, Antonescu sent out a public notification to the Romanian Regents, who were looking after [[King of Romania|King]] [[Michael I of Romania|Michael I]]. The text, which later became the LCC's [[Producerism|producerist]] platform, spoke of bankers, civil administrators, and industrialists as "parasites", and called for [[tax cut]]s on the less wealthy.Roșca & Vlad, p. 80 A peasant militant from [[Dolj County|Dolj]] detailed that agenda and proposed measures against the state apparatus, noting that a functionary could earn as much as 50 agricultural workers.Pandrea, p. 119 Historian Armin Heinen explains the economic mechanism leading to the establishment of the LCC as follows: "The [[Land reform in Romania|agrarian reform of 1917–1921]] created a need for currency, which could only be supplied by bank loans. Agriculturists had contracted high-interest loans, either to compensate the former landowner or to furnish their new or extended property with basic supplies, or merely—given the entirely too small plots they were left for production—to ensure their living income. As an effect of the economic crisis, produce prices fell [...]. The peasants could no longer make their payments, and consequently their properties were put up for sale."Heinen, p. 442 These issues were aggravated by Western [[protectionism]], which prevented exports, and by Soviet [[predatory pricing]], which reduced [[demand]]."Où va la Roumanie?", pp. 16–17 The Antonescu program was met with skepticism by various other specialists. A ''[[laissez-faire]]'' economist, Al. D. Neagu, argued that the League presented "inefficient, unjust and momentary palliatives" to a systemic crisis, none of which could reactivate demand.Neagu, pp. 337–339 Neagu also notes that the LCC's claims about usurers were largely dealt with by laws which limited [[repossession]], and that its program was "economically and morally unjustified".Neagu, pp. 334–335 Jurist [[Nicolae Dașcovici]] also suggested that measures such as those endorsed "by the League against Usury agitators" meant "a continuous and quickened fall of trust by the capital [market]—and as such implicitly the worsening of credit ratings." The "one cure", he proposed, was "liquidating the insolvent".[[Nicolae Dașcovici]], "Insănătoșirea creditului în România", in ''[[Societatea de Mâine]]'', Nr. 17–18/1930, p. 313 ===Growth and eclecticism=== The LCC was a complex and eclectic movement. The left-wing journalist [[Petre Pandrea]], who attended LCC meetings, saw the party as a "provisional alliance" of "the ''[[kulak]]'' and the hired hand".Pandrea, p. 115 Its sympathizers included [[Nicolae L. Lupu]], leader of the [[Peasants' Party–Lupu]] (PȚ–L) and a left-wing critic of National Peasantist economic policies. According to historian Pompiliu Tudoran, both Lupu and Antonescu's parties should be regarded as "center-left".Tudoran, p. 295 Lupu played a noted part in setting up the League,Ioan Scurtu, "Întemeierea și activitatea Partidului Țărănesc — dr. N. Lupu (1927—1934)", in ''Revista de Istorie'', Nr. 5/1976, p. 705 but was not present for its constitutive congress, being held up by partial elections in [[Hunedoara County]]. According to Pandrea, he had created around him a "popular myth" as a savior, but had never promised his peasant constituents any concrete form of [[debt relief]].Pandrea, pp. 116, 118 Lupu's faction within the LCC was represented by [[Ion D. Isac]]. An educationist and decorated veteran, Isac was both the organizer of the League's branch in Gorj and chair of the national secretariat.Șerban, pp. 233–239 Also joining the LCC in 1929 was a politically independent poet, [[George Tutoveanu]], who published denunciations of the bankers and stated that his party's mission was "to fight against suffering." In May 1930, the LCC inaugurated in Bucharest its own political newspaper, ''Jos Camăta'' ("Down with Usury"). From November 14, it had Constantin C. Iarca as its editor.Ileana-Stanca Desa, Dulciu Morărescu, Ioana Patriche, Cornelia Luminița Radu, Adriana Raliade, Iliana Sulică, ''Publicațiile periodice românești (ziare, gazete, reviste). Vol. IV: Catalog alfabetic 1925-1930'', p. 546. Bucharest: [[Editura Academiei]], 2003. {{ISBN|973-27-0980-4}} From October, it had a chapter in [[Bessarabia]], supervised by [[Pantelimon Erhan]].Nicolae Enciu, "Structura socio-profesională a populației Basarabiei interbelice între tradiţionalism și modernitate", in ''Hyperion. Revistă de Cultură'', Vol. 36, Issues 1–2–3, 2018, p. 129 Elsewhere, the League also won the adherence of Sterie Ionescu, who founded in [[Caracal, Romania|Caracal]] the newspaper ''Desrobirea'' ("Emancipation"), "at the service of plowmen, traders, and the League against Usury".Ileana-Stanca Desa, Elena Ioana Mălușanu, Cornelia Luminița Radu, Iuliana Sulică, ''Publicațiile periodice românești (ziare, gazete, reviste). Vol. V: Catalog alfabetic 1930–1935'', pp. 243, 374. Bucharest: [[Editura Academiei]], 2009. {{ISBN|978-973-27-1828-5}} On November 3, 1930, the LCC had absorbed into it ranks [[Eraclie Sterian]]'s Association of Mortgaged Owners and Debtors."Intrunirea Ligii contra cametei și proprietarilor ipotecați", in ''[[Adevărul]]'', November 4, 1930, p. 4 By 1931, it had a branch in [[Năsăud County]], with the mechanic Mihai Buta as one of its prominent members.Moldovan, p. 259 With its specific attacks on [[History of the Jews in Romania|Jewish]] creditors, the LCC also had radical-right tinges: Heinen sees it as an "antisemitic and markedly right-wing" party, or "protest movement".Heinen, pp. 153, 199, 379 The LCC's branch in [[Bukovina]] included a Colonel Ioan Niculcea, who also sympathized with the [[National-Christian Defense League]] (LANC).Bruja, pp. 241–242; Heinen, p. 195 In summer 1930, the latter movement had instigated "agrarian troubles of an antisemitic character","Où va la Roumanie?", p. 16 with Niculcea as an active instigator. In mid 1930, Niculcea was arrested alongside the LANC's [[Nichifor Robu]] and Dumitru Scriculeac, a measure which only resulted in more confrontations between their supporters and [[Romanian Police]].Bruja, p. 241 However, as noted at the time by ''La Revue Slave'', the LCC also challenged the core antisemitic tenets, by showing publicly that the "usurers" were highly active in [[Oltenia]], where Jews were virtually non-present."Où va la Roumanie?", pp. 17–18 In that region, the LCC was especially focused on denouncing the National Liberal banking monopoly.Scrutator, "Situația actuală și roadele campaniei contra partidelor. Nihilism politic în mase, mari nemulțumiri în cadrele politice. Greșelile guvernului au creat o situație intenabilă", in ''[[Adevărul]]'', May 21, 1931, p. 6 Eventually, in 1931, a LANC newspaper warned voters that the League was a "wolf in sheep's clothing", and merely a front for Lupu's party."Partidele, ca să mai aibă crezare, se ascund sub diferite nume", in ''Înfrățirea Românească'', Nr. 13/1931, p. 153 In other contexts, the LCC was regarded as a quasi-socialist movement or a front for the banned [[Romanian Communist Party]] (PCdR). As Pandrea notes, Lupu was suspected of being a "[[Bolshevik]]" by the banking lobby, but was merely a Romanian "[[Alexander Kerensky|Kerensky]]", his policies ones of compromise with the lenders.Pandrea, pp. 116–119 In one such report of January 1931, [[Argeș County]] authorities denounced the LCC as a front for both the PCdR and the [[Romanian Social Democratic Party (1927–48)|Social Democratic Party]] (PSDR).Dumitrescu & Dumitrescu, pp. 265–266 Such charges were disregarded by members of both groups. In its manifestos, the PSDR, which sided with the National Peasantists, dismissed the League and the PȚ–L as opportunistic movements, "created for the love of [[pork barrel]]s".[[Constantin Titel Petrescu]], ''Socialismul în România. 1835 – 6 septembrie 1940'', p. 418. Bucharest: Dacia Traiana, [n. y.] A more radical position was taken by the PCdR, whose 1931 congress listed LLC among the "fascist and semi-fascist" organisations used by the bourgeoisie and landowners in order to channel the discontent of the masses."Congresul al V-lea al Partidului Comunist din Romînia", in ''Documente din istoria Partidului Comunist din Romînia. 1929–1933'', pp. 35, 270, 370. Bucharest: Editura de stat pentru literatură politică, 1956 With Communists [[Communist Romania|taking power after World War II]], this view became replicated in official historiography.Georgescu, p. 326 However, in the 1960s, party historians such as Gheorghe Ioniță also reclaimed the League as one of the "democratic organizations created, steered, and influenced by the [communist party]".Cristina Diac, "O cotitură a destinului. Procesul lui Nicolae Ceaușescu din 1936", in Adrian Cioroianu (ed.), ''Comuniștii înainte de comunism: procese și condamnări ale ilegaliștilor din România'', p. 261. Bucharest: [[Editura Universității București]], 2014. {{ISBN|978-606-16-0520-0}} Researchers C. and F. Dumitrescu reached a similar conclusion, namely that the PCdR had a "tight connection" with the League.Dumitrescu & Dumitrescu, p. 266 Despite being joined by antisemites, the LCC was also open to members of various [[Minorities of Romania|ethnic minorities]]. Its regional chapter in the [[Banat]] was led by [[Stefan Frecôt]], a dissident and French-speaking member of the [[Danube Swabians|Danube Swabian]] community,Smaranda Vultur, ''Francezi în Banat, bănățeni în Franța'', pp. 48–49. Timișoara: Editura Marineasa, 2012. {{ISBN|978-973-631-698-2}} who was also briefly the national LCC's Vice President.Vasile Dudaș, "Ștefan Frecot", in ''Analele Banatului. Arheologie–Istorie'', Vol. XVI, 2008, p. 361 In Bukovina, where the LCC formed itself under the presidency of [[Dorimedont Popovici|Dorimedont "Dori" Popovici]] from May 1930, its affiliates included non-Romanians such as Carol Weltman, Victor Orobko, and Rudolf Müller.Florin-Răzvan Mihai, "Dinamica electorală a candidaților minoritari din Bucovina la alegerile generale din România interbelică", in Vasile Ciobanu, Sorin Radu (eds.), ''Partide politice și minorități naționale din România în secolul XX'', Vol. V, pp. 94, 100. Sibiu: TechnoMedia, 2010. {{ISBN|978-973-739-261-9}} [[Ukrainians in Romania|Ukrainian]] peasants were noted participants in Niculcea's anti-Jewish riot at [[Seliatyn|Seletin]]. ===1931 election and later history=== The League acknowledged [[Carol II of Romania|Carol II]]'s return to the Romanian throne, and "appealed to the sovereign that he take debtors under his protection.""Intrunirea Ligii contra cametei", in ''[[Adevărul]]'', March 22, 1932, p. 4 By March, the League and the Association of Mortgage Debtors were proselytizing with large-scale awareness campaigns, often developed around [[agricultural show]]s. These offered venues for airing LCC slogans, including: ''Dobânda este un furt ce nu trebuie plătit'' ("Interest is theft that we should not cover").Dumitrescu & Dumitrescu, p. 273 Carol toppled the National Peasantist cabinet in April, assigning [[Nicolae Iorga]] as his [[Prime Minister of Romania|Prime Minister]]. As the latter noted, the appointment coincided with great turmoil, during which the LCC was preparing "an actual peasants' revolt" at Gorj.[[Nicolae Iorga]], ''Doi ani de restaurație. Ce a fost, ce am vrut, ce am putut'', pp. 29–30. Vălenii de Munte: Datina Românească, 1932. {{OCLC|45882093}} This was also suggested by Pandrea, who recalled the "[[1907 Romanian Peasants' Revolt|1907 atmosphere]]" and "pre-revolutionary" feel of the LCC congress in [[Craiova]].Pandrea, p. 114 According to journalist Calman Blumenfeld-Scrutator, the "extraordinarily energetic" League was also especially strong in the Banat, where it looked like a real threat to the establishment. In the [[Romanian general election, 1931|June 1931 general elections]], convened by Iorga, the LCC ran under a [[sun cross]] logo (⊕)."Haosul electoral", in ''[[Realitatea Ilustrată]]'', Nr. 285, July 1935, p. 28 It formed a loose alliance with the left-wing agrarian [[Democratic Peasants' Party–Stere]] (PȚD–S). The latter registered on separate lists, but only put up candidates in Bessarabia.Heinen, pp. 152, 153 By then, however, some members of the far-right wing had left the League: Col. Niculcea set up a Beetroot Cultivators' Collective (''Obștea Cultivatorilor de Sfeclă''), which caucused with the fascist [[Iron Guard]].Heinen, pp. 153, 195 Far-right groups were nominally repressed during the election, with both Niculicea and Robu returning to jail,Bruja, pp. 241–242 but [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Romania)|Internal Affairs]], then under [[Constantin Argetoianu]], failed to take significant action on that front. At the time, the bulk of its surveillance activity was still focused on the LCC, the PCdR, and the [[Peasant Workers' Bloc]].N. Petrescu, p. 316 According to Scrutator, the LCC policy of presenting in peasant candidates "makes insomniacs from both the leaders of government organizations as well as those of the opposition." As noted by historian Niculae Petrescu, the Democratic Peasantists had more to gain from their partnership with the LCC, increasing its share of the vote nationally. However, the alliance only received 2.8% of the vote nationally, winning them six seats in the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Assembly of Deputies]]. The LCC took one seat and the PȚD–S took five.[[Dieter Nohlen]], Philip Stöver, ''Elections in Europe: A Data Handbook''. Baden-Baden: Nomos, 2010, p. 1601. {{ISBN|978-3-8329-5609-7}}. See also ''Politics and Political Parties...'', p. 57. See also N. Petrescu, p. 315; Moldovan, p. 261 The party also formed a cartel with the PȚ–L, which granted it as a favor an extra seat, representing Gorj."Electorale. D. dr. Lupu despre denunțarea cartelului de către Liga contra cametei", in ''[[Adevărul]]'', June 17, 1932, p. 5 Here, the two groups had gathered 3,940 votes between them.Tudoran, p. 294 The courtesy seat went to Isac, who had been arrested for sedition during the campaign, forcing the authorities to release him.Șerban, p. 238 The [[Democratic Nationalist Party (Romania)|Democratic Nationalist Party]] (PND) and its allies emerged victorious from the campaign, returning Iorga as Prime Minister. His new administration incorporated former LCC cadres, appointing Tutoveanu as the [[Prefect (Romania)|prefect]] of [[Tutova County]].Clapa, p. 8 The LCC also ran in the partial elections for the Assembly seat in that county (April 1932), separate from Lupu's own PȚ–L. The seat was taken by the Iron Guard's [[Corneliu Zelea Codreanu]], who won 26% of the vote; the LCC had 13.7%, and the PȚ–L 6.2%.Heinen, pp. 199–200, 379 According to Heinen, the League still managed to draw votes away from the Iron Guard's niche, upsetting its growth.Heinen, p. 379 The LCC opted to present its own candidates in the [[Romanian general election, 1932|elections of July 1932]]. It thus denounced the PȚ–L alliance, allegedly because Lupu had refused to assign an eligible position in [[Alba County]] to Antonescu. The group failed to win any seats, but its leadership still met in August 1932, when it presented a new set of political demands."Intrunirea Ligei contra cametei", in ''[[Adevărul]]'', August 9, 1932, p. 3 Largely rendered ineffectual by the adoption of debt relief and anti-usury legislation under the Iorga cabinet, it supported the application of such laws once they were placed in peril by the National Peasantist government of [[Alexandru Vaida-Voevod]]. At the time, it was speculated that the LCC would form a "spontaneous" alliance with the PND and other parties.T. L., "Acțiunea pentru apărarea conversiunii", in ''[[Adevărul]]'', August 9, 1932, p. 6 However, the LCC voted to dissolve itself later in 1932. An association called League Against Usury still existed in 1934 in Bucharest, collaborating with the Association of Mortgaged Owners and Debtors on a Front for Urban Reclamation (''Frontul Asanării Urbane''). The LCC's Gorj chapter, presided upon by Magherescu, had merged into Argetoianu's [[Agrarian Union Party]], while Sterie Ionescu founded a Front of Debtors, and, in 1935, sought to reestablish the [[National Agrarian Party (Romania)|National Agrarian Party]].Dumitru Botar, "Din presa romanațeană de altădată (III)", in ''Memoria Oltului și Romanaților'', Issue 4/2017, p. 32 Before the [[Romanian general election, 1937|general election of December 1937]], the sun cross logo was taken up by a [[Radical Peasants' Party]], under [[Grigore Iunian]].See list published alongside N. Papatansiu, "Războiul electoral", in ''[[Realitatea Ilustrată]]'', Issue 569, December 1937, p. 5 Antonescu himself set up another group, the (allegedly fascist) League for the Defense of Private Property.Georgescu, p. 343 By the start of World War II, he reemerged as a right-wing critic of the Iron Guard, whom he accused of fomenting violent dissent among his students.Valentin Săndulescu, "Convertiri și reconvertiri: elite academice și culturale și schimbare politică în România anilor 1930–1960", in Cristian Vasile (ed.), ''"Ne trebuie oameni!". Elite intelectuale și transformări istorice în România modernă și contemporană'', p. 167. Târgoviște: [[Nicolae Iorga Institute of History]] & Editura Cetatea de Scaun, 2017. {{ISBN|978-606-537-385-3}} Isac remained in national politics with Lupu's party, also setting up a Ploughmen's Syndicate; he withdrew from public affairs during World War II, but was for a while promoted under communism.Șerban, pp. 237–239 ==Notes== {{Reflist|3}} ==References== *"Où va la Roumanie?", in ''Le Monde Slave'', Vol. 2, No. 4, April 1932, pp. 1–38. *''Politics and Political Parties in Roumania''. London: International Reference Library Publishers Co., 1936. {{OCLC|252801505}} *Radu Florian Bruja, "Nichifor Robu – trepte către monografia unui politician antisemit", in ''Anuarul Institutului de Istorie George Barițiu din Cluj-Napoca. Supliment'', Vol. LII, 2013, pp. 235–256. *Gheorghe Clapa, "Gheorghe Tutoveanu – prefect de Tutova (13 aprilie 1931 – 31 mai 1932)", in ''[[Academia Bârlădeană]]'', Nr. 20/2005, pp. 7–9. *C. Dumitrescu, F. Dumitrescu, "Frămîntări sociale în județul Argeș în anii crizei economice (1929—1933)", in ''Studii și Comunicări'', Vol. II, 1969, pp. 263–277. *Titu Georgescu, "Activitatea Comitetului național antifascist (1933—1934)", in ''Studii. Revistă de Istorie'', Nr. 2/1961, pp. 323–353. *Armin Heinen, ''Legiunea 'Arhanghelul Mihail': o contribuție la problema fascismului internațional''. Bucharest: [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], 2006. {{ISBN|973-50-1158-1}} *[[Victor Moldovan]], ''Memoriile unui politician din perioada interbelică. Vol. I''. Cluj-Napoca: Presa Universitară Clujeană, 2016. {{ISBN|978-973-595-971-5}}. *Al. D. Neagu, "Problema datoriilor particulare", in ''Buletinul Institutului Economic Românesc'', Nr. 5–6/1930, pp. 316–339. *[[Petre Pandrea]], "Prerevoluționar", in ''Utopia'', Nr. 5–6/1930, pp. 114–119. *Niculae Petrescu, "Un experiment politic interbelic—guvernul de tehnicieni", in ''Muzeul Național'', Vol. I, Issue 17, 2005, pp. 303–322. *Ion Gh. Roșca, Liviu Bogdan Vlad, ''Rectorii Academiei de Studii Economice din București''. Bucharest: [[Bucharest Academy of Economic Studies]], 2013. {{ISBN|978-606-505-672-5}} *Al. Doru Șerban, ''Personalități care au fost în Gorj''. Târgu Jiu: Măiastra, 2009. {{ISBN|978-606-516-133-7}} *Pompiliu Tudoran, "Gorjul în contextul electoral al Olteniei din cel de-al patrulea deceniu. Unele considerații statistice", in ''Litua. Studii și Cercetări'', 1982, pp. 291–296. {{Historical Romanian political parties}} [[Category:1929 establishments in Romania]] [[Category:1932 disestablishments in Romania]] [[Category:Agrarian parties in Romania]] [[Category:Defunct agrarian political parties]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Romania]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 1932]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1929]] [[Category:Single-issue political parties]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
Ministry of Health |nativename = وزارة الصحة |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = Saudi Ministry of Health.JPG |logo_width =150px |logo_caption =[[Emblem of Saudi Arabia]] |formed = {{start date and age|1950}} |jurisdiction = [[Saudi Arabia]] |headquarters = [[Riyadh]] |coordinates = {{Coord|24|39|28|N|46|42|56|E|display=title}} |chief1_name = Dr. Tawfiq Al-Rabiah |chief1_position = Minister |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |chief3_name = |chief3_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = {{url|http://www.moh.gov.sa}} }} '''Ministry of Health''' ({{lang-ar|وزارة الصحة}}) is the ministry responsible for the health of the citizens of [[Saudi Arabia]]. The current minister is Dr. [[Tawfiq Al Rabiah]]. ==History and profile== In 1925, Saudi Arabia's first public health department was established in [[Makkah]].{{cite web|title=Kingdom of Saudi Arabia Ministry of Health Detects System Threats and Policy Violations 25% Faster with Fewer Analysts|url=http://www.oracle.com/us/corporate/customers/customersearch/moh-1-audit-vault-ss-2145224.html|publisher=Oracle|accessdate=8 September 2014}} The department was responsible for building hospitals and healthcare centers and issuing and enforcing regulations to provide necessary standards for practicing [[medicine]] and [[pharmacology]]. A public health council was also established to address the growing need for healthcare services and it was the highest-level supervisory board, overseeing all aspects of the country’s healthcare services. Then, these health-care institutions were transformed into a ministerial body in 1950.{{cite book|author=David E. Long|title=Culture and Customs of Saudi Arabia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VKisHwiTxJQC&pg=PR15|accessdate=25 January 2014|date=1 January 2005|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-32021-7|page=15}} [[Abdullah bin Faisal Al Saud]] was the first health minister.{{cite news|last=Ahmad|first=Mahmoud|title=Abdullah Al-Faisal Passes Away|url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/298147|accessdate=25 March 2012|newspaper=Arab News|date=9 May 2007}} The ministry is based in [[Riyadh]].[http://www.s-ge.com/de/filefield-private/files/2816/field_blog_public_files/4865 Basic addresses] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224033210/http://www.s-ge.com/de/filefield-private/files/2816/field_blog_public_files/4865 |date=24 February 2014 }} OSCE. September 2011. Retrieved 5 February 2014. Health-care services in Saudi Arabia are provided by several public and private agencies. However, the ministry is the major planner and provider of these services.{{cite book|author=Mohammed H. Mufti|title=Healthcare Development Strategies in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8h-YENxCRYUC&pg=PA9|accessdate=8 September 2014|date=29 February 2000|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-0-306-46314-3|page=9}} ==Ministers== * Abdullah bin Faisal Al Saud 1950 * Hamad bin Abdullah Al Manie 2003-2009 * [[Abdullah bin Abdulaziz Al Rabiah]] 2009-2014{{cite news|author=Mustapha Ajbaili|title=Saudi Health Minister ‘relieved of his post’|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/04/21/Saudi-Health-Minister-relieved-of-duties-.html|accessdate=27 June 2014|work=Al Arabiya|date=21 April 2014}} * [[Adel Fakeih]] 2014 (acting) * Dr. [[Mohammed Al-Hayaza]] 2014 - January 2015 {{cite news|author=Saudi Gazette|title=King appoints 8 new ministers|url=http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentid=20141209226978|accessdate=12 December 2014|work=Saudi Gazette|date=9 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141215094407/http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentid=20141209226978|archivedate=15 December 2014|df=dmy-all}} * Ahmed Al-Khatib January 2015 - April 2015 {{cite news|author=Arab News|title=Health minister spells out his revamp plans|url=http://www.arabnews.com/saudi-arabia/news/698756|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Arab News|date=3 February 2015}} * Mohamad Al ash-Sheikh April 2015 - April 2015 {{cite news|author=sapq news-سبق|title=بأمر الملك سلمان.. إعفاء وزير الصحة أحمد الخطيب من منصبه|url=http://sabq.org/GC3gde|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=sapq|date=11 April 2015}} * Eng. Khalid Alfalih April 2015 – May 2016 * Dr. Tawfiq Al-Rabiah May 2016 - ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.moh.gov.sa/}} * https://twitter.com/SaudiMOH * https://twitter.com/tfrabiah {{DEFAULTSORT:Ministry of Health}} [[Category:1950 establishments in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Ministries established in 1950|Saudi Arabia, Health]] [[Category:Government organisations of Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Health in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Health ministries|Saudi Arabia]] {{SaudiArabia-stub}}

[[Image:Morena Herrera 2018.jpg|thumb|Morena Herrera (2018).]] '''Morena Herrera''' is a Salvadoran feminist and social activist, noted for her work against her country's ban on abortion. During the [[Salvadoran Civil War]], which ended in 1992, Herrera served as a left-wing freedom fighter for the [[Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front]] (FMLN) against the United States-supported government. She has been particularly active against abortion since it was abolished in 1997, and in 2009 began working with the Citizen’s Group for the Decriminalization of Abortion, which she now heads. Herrera was named one of the [[BBC 100 Women]] in 2016 for her contributions to women's rights in El Salvador.
==Biography== Active in campaigning for social change from a young age, during the [[Salvadoran Civil War]], which ended in 1992,<ref name="Am"/> Herrera served as a left-wing freedom fighter. She fought for over ten years with the [[Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front]] (FMLN) against the United States-supported government.<ref name="Independent">{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/el-salvador-morena-herrera-meet-the-former-marxist-guerrilla-fighting-for-reproductive-rights-in-a-a7119711.html|title= El Salvador: Meet the former Marxist guerrilla fighting for reproductive rights in a country where there are none|publisher=''The Independent''|date=5 July 2016|accessdate=11 December 2016}}</ref>
Herrera was outspoken on the Peace Accords, signed in 1992, which she saw as deeply problematic for women's rights in El Salvador. She has said of them: "Those accords left big holes when it came to women’s rights. I realized I had to fight another way. Women’s rights are human rights and they have to be a priority." The situation for women and abortion has worsened since 1997, when changes in the penal code made abortion completely illegal, when it had previously been acceptable in severe cases where a woman's life was at risk or she had been raped.<ref name="Am">{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/campaigns/2015/01/defying-el-salvador-s-total-ban-on-abortion/|title=Defying El Salvador’s total ban on abortion|publisher=Amnesty International|date=15 January 2015|accessdate=11 December 2016}}</ref> Due to the country being strictly Catholic, abortion is considered unacceptable, even for pregnant teenage girls who face many problems.<ref name="Independent"/>
Since the ban on abortion in El Salvador was passed in 1998, over 600 women accused of having an abortion have been sent to jail for up to forty years. The worst part of this unfortunate circumstance is that in most of these cases, the women had a miscarriage. Now they must deal with the sorrow of losing their child while being jailed for a 'crime' they did not commit. "Las 17" is a group of jailed women whose freedom Herrera and her colleagues have fought for. Although a few these women have been freed, despite all the efforts by Herrera and her colleagues, many more women have been convicted and sent to jail for the same crime. Herrera says that the government does not recognize women's reproductive rights, despite the risks a pregnancy places on the mother. Currently, a third of pregnancies in El Salvador come from teenage mothers, this could be partly due to young women being raped by the horrendous gangs that are prominent near San Salvador, the nation's capital. Therefore, these young women are more subject to having pregnancy complications since they are still growing and maturing themselves. Political figures don't want to discard the ban on abortion because they fear the church and certain organizations such as the "Yes to Life Foundation", will not elect them back to office. The idea of 'a woman's sole purpose is to be a mother and take care of the house' is a main one for the church and society of El Salvador, leading to the lack of support for a woman to be in control of her body. To make matters worse, contraception is very hard to obtain for most women and if they do obtain some, it usually does not work properly. Herrera hopes to have make change in the legal rights for women while Salvador Sanchez Céren is still president (until 2019), but while his job and life are on the line facing the gangs and society, the changes towards women's rights has been an incredibly slow process. Despite the plethora of obstacles Herrera still has to overcome and the frequent threats on her life and the life of her family members, she continues to work tediously each day towards a better, consented life for all women in El Salvador. <ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/el-salvador-morena-herrera-meet-the-former-marxist-guerrilla-fighting-for-reproductive-rights-in-a-a7119711.html</ref><ref>https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/campaigns/2015/01/defying-el-salvador-s-total-ban-on-abortion/</ref>
Since 2009, Herrera has worked with the Citizen’s Group for the Decriminalization of Abortion, which she now heads.<ref name="Am"/> In 2013 she was outspoken when the [[Supreme Court of El Salvador]] denied an abortion to a terminally ill woman, who stood no chance of surviving the birth, calling them "irresponsible".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-22712756|title=El Salvador court denies seriously ill woman abortion|publisher=BBC|date=13 May 2013|accessdate=11 December 2016}}</ref> Her work was subject to a report by [[Amnesty International]] in January 2015,<ref name="Am"/> and in 2016 she was named one of the [[BBC 100 Women]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-38012048|title=BBC 100 Women 2016: Who is on the list?|publisher=BBC|date=21 November 2016|accessdate=11 December 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Herrera, Morena}}

{{Communist Romania}} The nationalization of the [[means of production]] was a measure taken by [[Romania]]'s new [[Romanian Communist Party|Communist]] authorities in order to lay the foundation of socialism. The act that allowed this measure to take place was Law 119, adopted by the [[Great National Assembly]] on June 11, 1948. Article 1 decreed subject to nationalization "all the wealth of the soil not in the property of the state at the time of entry into force of the [[1948 Constitution of Romania|Constitution of the Romanian People's Republic]], as well as individual enterprises, societies of any type and private industrial, bank, insurance, mining, transport and telecommunications associations". Nationalized (generally without any form of compensation) were 8,894 industrial, mining, transport, banking and insurance companies, followed in November 1948 by 383 cinemas and medical-sanitary facilities. By 1950, the measure was applied to chemical enterprises, pharmacies and remaining economic entities.
The nationalization<ref>mostly thanks to Decrees 92/1950, 111/1951, 224/1951, 513/1953, and 409/1955 - [http://www.cdep.ro/pls/legis/legis_pck.htp_act_text?idt=8797 direct link to the 92/1950 decree (Romanian Chamber of Deputies)]</ref> also included a significant number of homes. The figure of around 400,000 buildings is regularly mentioned. According to Societatea Academică din România (SAR) between 241.000 and 600.000 properties<ref>SAR Brief Policy n°34, September 2008, page 5 : [http://www.sar.org.ro/files/330_Policy%20memo34EN.pdf direct link to the survey]</ref> were affected by the measure.
The nationalization begun in 1948, together with the [[Collectivization in Romania|collectivization of agriculture]] (1949–62), were decisive in undoing the capitalist economy and establishing a socialist economy based on state-owned or cooperative property.
After the fall of communism in Romania, the state has tried to compensate homeowners and enterprise owners who could not recover their houses, industries, or lands. A special fund dedicated to compensation was created in 2005: [[Fondul Proprietatea]].
==See also== *[[Economy of the Socialist Republic of Romania]]

[[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]]
''Social:''
[[Right-wing politics|Right-wing]] | headquarters = [[Chişinău]] | international = ''none'' | european = ''none'' | leader1_title = Parliamentary group leader | leader1_name = [[Zinaida Greceanîi]] | seats1_title = [[Parliament of the Republic of Moldova|Parliament]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|24|101|hex={{Party of Socialists of the Republic of Moldova/meta/color}}}} | seats2_title = [[Administrative divisions of Moldova|District]] Presidents | seats2 = {{Composition bar|2|32|hex={{Party of Socialists of the Republic of Moldova/meta/color}}}} | colours = Red | website = [http://socialistii.md socialistii.md] }} The '''Party of Socialists of the Republic of Moldova''' ({{lang-ro|Partidul Socialiştilor din Republica Moldova}}, '''PSRM'''; {{lang-ru|Партия социалистов Республики Молдова}}, ''Partija socialistov Respubliki Moldova'') is a [[Russophilia|pro-Russian]] [[democratic socialist]], [[nationalist]] and [[populist]] [[List of political parties in Moldova|political party]] in [[Moldova]]. Between 2005 and 2011 it was known as the Party of Socialists of Moldova "Motherland" (''Partidul Socialiştilor din Moldova «Patria-Rodina»'', PSMPR). The party has now largely succeeded the [[Party of Communists of the Republic of Moldova]] (PCRM) in terms of election results and opinion polling, winning 20.5% against 17.5% in the [[Moldovan parliamentary election, 2014]] and currently{{When|date=April 2018}} polling at around 50% against PCRM's 3%.{{cite web|url=http://www.timpul.md/articol/rezultate-sondaj-socio-politic-fop---daca-duminica-ar-avea-loc-alegeri-psrm---503-pas--259-pdm---62-ppda---41-i-pcrm-37-123209.html|publisher=Ziarul Timpul și Fondul Opiniei Publice|language=Moldovan|title=DOC / Rezultatele sondajului socio-politic FOP. Dacă duminică ar avea loc alegeri: PSRM - 50,3%, PAS -25,9%, PDM - 6,2%, PPDA - 4,1 și PCRM 3,7%}} ==History== The PSRM was founded in 1997 by members of the [[Socialist Party of Moldova]]. The Founding Congress took place on 29 June 1997 in [[Chişinău]]. Veronica Abramciuc and Eduard Smirnov were elected as co-chairmen of the new party.{{cite web|url=http://www.e-democracy.md/parties/psmpr/|title=Partidul Socialiştilor din Republica Moldova (PSRM) / partide.md|publisher=|accessdate=25 February 2015}} The party obtained 0,59% of votes in [[Moldovan parliamentary election, 1998|1998 election]], failing to elect any representative. In [[Moldovan parliamentary election, 2001|2001 election]] the party formed the electoral bloc "Unity", together with the [[Republican Party of Moldova]]: the bloc obtained 0,46% of votes, failing to elect any representative. In 2006 elections the party formed the [[Electoral Bloc Motherland|electoral bloc "Motherland"]], together with the [[Socialist Party of Moldova]]: the bloc obtained 4,9% of votes and did not elect any representatives. The party did not participate in 2009 and 2010 elections, endorsing the [[Party of Communists of the Republic of Moldova|Party of Communists of Moldova]] (PCRM) instead; party chairman Veronica Abramciuc was included in PCRM list and elected to the Parliament. In 2011, [[Igor Dodon]], former member of the PCRM, joined the party, and was elected as its chairman on 18 December 2011.[https://archive.is/20120802030117/http://www.infoprut.ro/2011/noul-presedinte-al-partidului-socialistilor-este-igor-dodon.html Infoprut.ro] Subsequently a Socialist Group, which included Dodon, Veronica Abramciuc and [[Zinaida Greceanîi]], was set up in the [[Parliament of the Republic of Moldova|Parliament]].{{cite web|url=http://www.regnum.ru/news/fd-abroad/1469079.html&usg=ALkJrhhbkWYaNReUgpwfDLsky3FVTifItg|title="Ãðóïïà Äîäîíà" ñîçäàëà â ïàðëàìåíòå Ìîëäàâèè ôðàêöèþ ñîöèàëèñòîâ|work=ÈÀ REGNUM|accessdate=25 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225152505/http://www.regnum.ru/news/fd-abroad/1469079.html%26usg%3DALkJrhhbkWYaNReUgpwfDLsky3FVTifItg|archivedate=25 February 2015|df=}} The party won the [[Moldovan parliamentary election, 2014|2014 general election]] with over 20% of the vote. The party remained in opposition, as two pro-EU center-right parties managed to form a [[Minority government|minority]] [[Gaburici Cabinet|cabinet]] with the external support of the PCRM.{{cite web|last1=Timuş|first1=Natalia|title=A democratic and European stern test for Moldovan political elite|url=http://whogoverns.eu/a-democratic-and-european-stern-test-for-moldovan-political-elite/|website=Party Systems and Governments Observatory|accessdate=30 March 2015|date=23 March 2015}} In the [[Moldovan presidential election, 2016|Moldovan presidential elections of 2016]] party leader Igor Dodon was elected as new President of Moldova. Following the election, Dodon stepped down as party chairman and was replaced by [[Zinaida Greceanîi]]. == Political positions == The party has an anti-[[NATO]], anti-[[European Union]], anti-[[Romania|Romanian]], and pro-[[Russia|Russian]] stance.{{Cite web|url=https://jamestown.org/program/russias-new-moldovan-favorite-igor-dodons-socialist-party/|title=Russia’s New Moldovan Favorite: Igor Dodon’s Socialist Party|last=Socor|first=Vladimir|date=|website=Eurasia Daily Monitor Volume|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.timpul.md/articol/psrm-patria-noastra-este-moldova--limba-noastra-este-moldoveneasca--122904.html|title=PSRM: „Patria noastră este Moldova. Limba noastră este moldovenească ”|last=|first=|date=|website=Timpul.md|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Party members have a [[USSR]] nostalgia and support the so-called ″Moldovan language and Moldovan [[Ethnic group|ethnicity]]", a thesis constructed by [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[propaganda]].{{Cite web|url=https://ecpr.eu/Filestore/PaperProposal/438e9bc3-a592-4200-99da-b6b89af0c1dc.pdf|title=The Construction, Deconstruction and Conflict of National Identities in Moldova|last=Cojocaru|first=Lee|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Although the party is anti-Romanian, party members have [[Romania|Romanian]] citizenship, for example members of [[Parliament of the Republic of Moldova|Parliament]] [[Alla Dolinţă]], [[Anatolie Labuneţ]], [[Adrian Lebedinschi]], [[Corneliu Furculiţa]], [[Ghenadi Mitriuc]], [[Radu Mudreac]].{{Cite web|url=http://jurnal.md/ro/politic/2018/1/5/doc-deputatii-psrm-cu-pasaport-romanesc-care-acum-jumatate-de-an-ca-au-depus-cereri-sa-li-se-retraga-cetatenia-romana-au-mintit/|title=DOC: Deputaţii PSRM cu paşaport românesc, care acum jumătate de an spuneau că au depus cereri să li se retragă cetăţenia română, au MINŢIT|last=|first=|date=|website=Jurnal.md|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The party strongly opposes [[LGBT rights in Moldova]]. Despite officially associating itself with the left wing movement, the party is working with nationalist, right wing and religious movements to counter the "promotion of vice spread with the help of the US in Moldova."[http://www.moldova.org/en/lgbt-solidarity-march-held/ LGBT solidarity march in Moldova stopped due to fear of clashes with orthodox counter protesters] The party has links to [[right-wing populist]] political parties across Europe, including the [[Europe of Nations and Freedom]] parliamentary group.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=onPJiMxOZnw ENF Group invited to the new Moldovan president's investiture] Despite labeling itself as socialist, PSRM is not affiliated to socialist international organizations, like the [[Socialist International]], the [[Progressive Alliance]] or the [[Party of European Socialists]] (all positions held by the [[Democratic Party of Moldova]]). == Party leaders == * Veronica Abramciuc (1997-2011) * [[Igor Dodon]] (2011-2016) * [[Zinaida Greceanîi]] (from 2016) ==Electoral results== The PSRM participated in the Moldovan parliamentary elections in 1998 and 2001 without success. In the [[Moldovan parliamentary election, 2005|2005 legislative elections]] the party contested as part of the [[Electoral Bloc Motherland]] and received 4.97% votes, which was not sufficient to enter parliament, as it did not pass the electoral threshold of 6.0%. At the 2009 legislative elections in [[Moldovan parliamentary election, April 2009|April]] and [[Moldovan parliamentary election, July 2009|July]] and at the [[Moldovan parliamentary election, 2010|2010 legislative election]] it supported the [[Party of Communists of the Republic of Moldova]]. Its leader, Veronica Abramciuc, was included in the PCRM candidates list.{{cite web|url=http://www.e-democracy.md/en/elections/parliamentary/2009/electoral-news/20090211/|title=Election News from February 11, 2009 / Elections 2009|publisher=|accessdate=25 February 2015}} ===Parliament=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Use South African English|date=August 2013}} [[File:The Poor People's Alliance Outside the Constitutional Court 14 May 2009.jpg|small|right|350px|Members of the Poor People's Alliance Outside the Constitutional Court, 14 May 2009]]
'''The Poor People's Alliance''' is a network of radical [[grassroots]] movements in [[South Africa]].<ref>[http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/Content.aspx?id=124776 Voices of poor must be heard], Editorial, ''Business Day'', 25 October 2010</ref><ref>[http://ceasefiremagazine.co.uk/columns/the-anti-imperialist/the-anti-imperialist-south-africa-a-revolution-in-progress/ South Africa: A Revolution in Progress], ''Ceasefire'', 9 January 2009</ref> It was formed in 2008 after the Action Alliance, formed in December 2006, was expanded to include two more [[Organization|organisations]].<ref>[http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2009/01/12/18562116.php The Struggle for Land & Housing in Post-Apartheid South Africa by Toussaint Losier, Left Turn, January 2009]</ref>
The following [[Organization|organisations]] are members of the alliance:
#[[Abahlali baseMjondolo]] in the [[province]] of [[KwaZulu-Natal]]. #Abahlali baseMjondolo in the [[province]] of the [[Western Cape]]. #The [[Landless People's Movement]] in the province of [[Gauteng]]. #The [[Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign]] in the province of the [[Western Cape]]. #The Rural Network of [[KwaZulu-Natal]].<ref>[http://www.zcommunications.org/znet/viewArticle/21529 'Participatory Society: Urban Space & Freedom', by Chris Spannos, Z-Net, 29 May 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090606072510/http://www.zcommunications.org/znet/viewArticle/21529 |date=6 June 2009 }}</ref><ref>[http://ceasefiremagazine.co.uk/columns/the-anti-imperialist/the-anti-imperialist-south-africa-a-revolution-in-progress/ South Africa: A Revolution in Progress], ''Ceasefire'', 9 January 2009</ref>
The Poor People's Alliance refuses [[Election|electoral]] [[politics]]<ref>[http://www.sundaytribune.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=5370984] Possibilities for other options at polls, Imraan Buccus, Sunday Tribune, 28 February 2010</ref> and resolved to [[boycott]] the 2009 national elections under the slogan "[[No Land! No House! No Vote!]]".<ref>See 'Post Annual General Meeting Speech by S'bu Zikode' at http://www.abahlali.org/node/4666</ref><ref>[http://cozop.com/divergences_revue_libertaire_internationale_en_ligne/south_africa_anc_attacks_shack_dwellers_movements ANC Attacks Shack Dwellers Movements]</ref><ref>[http://soundzofthesouth.blogspot.com/2011/03/by-voting-we-are-only-choosing-our.html By Voting We Are Only Choosing Our Oppressors], Soundz of the South</ref>
The Poor People's Alliance has supported the struggle of the [[eMacambini]] [[Community]] against [[mass]] eviction by [[Ruwaad Holdings]] and KwaZulu-Natal Premier [[S'bu Ndebele]] and the [[African National Congress]] Provincial [[Government]] of KwaZulu-Natal.<ref>See 'Ten Thousand to March on S’bu Ndebele in Protest at eMacambini Evictions' at http://www.abahlali.org/node/4584</ref>
==International links==
The Chicago Anti-Eviction Campaign states that it has been influenced by the Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign and the Poor People's [[Alliance]].<ref>[http://chicagoantieviction.org/2012/02/february-rent-party-fundraiser-for.html February "Rent Party" Fundraiser for Freedom], ''Chicago Anti-Eviction Campaign''</ref>

'''Psychic driving''' was a psychiatric procedure of the 1950s and 1960s in which patients were subjected to a continuously repeated audio message on a looped tape to alter their behaviour. In psychic driving, patients were often exposed to hundreds of thousands of repetitions of a single statement over the course of their treatment. They were also concurrently administered muscular paralytic drugs such as [[curare]] to subdue them for the purposes of exposure to the looped message(s). The procedure was pioneered by [[Donald Ewen Cameron|Dr. D. Ewen Cameron]], and used and funded by the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA's]] [[Project MKUltra]] program in [[Canada]].
==Psychiatry and MKUltra==
The psychic driving procedure was a chronological precursor to Cameron's ''depatterning'', the latter involving massive doses of [[electroconvulsive therapy]] (ECT) combined with similarly large doses of [[psychedelic drug]]s (such as [[Lysergic acid diethylamide|LSD]]). The intent was to break down the subject's personality—theoretically ''psychic driving'' could then be used with some efficacy in establishing a new personality.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0010-440X(62)80015-7 |vauthors=Cameron DE, Lohrenz JG, Handcock KA |title=The depatterning treatment of schizophrenia |journal=Compr Psychiatry |date=April 1962 |volume=3 |issue=2 |pages=65–76 |pmid=13875932}}</ref> In Cameron's depatterning, the ECT would often continue to be administered despite the manifestation of convulsive fits, which were consensually considered to be contraindications to normal and safe ECT procedure. Such biologically and psychologically devastating procedures, adopted internationally by the psychiatric establishment, were largely abolished by the time the CIA was brought before a Senate Hearing (1977)<ref>Transcript of the 1977 Senate Hearing can be found [http://glownavy.com/senate%20hearing%201977.pdf here] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501020528/http://glownavy.com/senate%20hearing%201977.pdf |date=2011-05-01 }}, [http://www.saferchildren.net/print/senate01.pdf here] or [http://prernalal.com/banned%20books/1977%20Senate%20Hearing%20on%20MKULTRA.pdf here]{{dead link|date=April 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> for its involvement and funding of Cameron's experimental activities—as part of the MKULTRA program.<ref>For information on the 1977 Court Action against the CIA see: {{cite journal |title=Anatomy of A Public Interest Case Against the CIA |vauthors=Rauh Jr JL, Turner JC |journal=Hamline Journal of Public Law & Policy |year=1990 |volume=11 |page=307 |url=https://scholar.google.com.au/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=info:WUJ6bgb97PsJ:scholar.google.com/&output=viewport&pg=1}}</ref> The topic of Cameron's psychic driving is dealt with in some detail in the docudrama entitled ''[[The Sleep Room (1998 film)|The Sleep Room]]'' (1998) directed by [[Anne Wheeler]].<ref>{{IMDb title|0138104|The Sleep Room}}</ref>
==Other uses==
Similar techniques are alleged to have been used in the kidnapping and death of CIA operative [[William Francis Buckley]] by [[Aziz al-Abub]], a medical doctor from Beirut who was seen as epitomizing medical torture. Aziz al-Abub, also known as Ibrahim al-Nadhir, was known for using his medical training to refine torture techniques. His techniques were shown to be closely connected to the CIA-developed torture techniques.<ref>{{cite book |title= Journey into Madness: Medical Torture and the Mind Controllers |author=[[Gordon Thomas (author)|Gordon Thomas]] |publisher=Bantam Press |date=1988-08-01 |isbn=0593011422}}</ref> As with the CIA, he used drugs to make it easier to handle those he tortured, carefully determined how long to keep a prisoner hooded and when to isolate them and other techniques seen as medical torture.
==In popular culture==
Initially, in the hit [[NBC]] TV series ''[[Hannibal (TV series)|Hannibal]]'', [[Dr. Frederick Chilton|Dr. Chilton]] uses psychic driving on a patient of the Baltimore State Hospital for the Criminally Insane, Dr. Abel Gideon (played by [[Eddy Izzard]]), to convince him that he is the main antagonist of the series, the Chesapeake ripper. Later in the series psychic driving is alluded to by the main character [[Hannibal Lecter|Dr. Hannibal Lecter]] as a means to convince FBI profiler [[Will Graham (Character)|Will Graham]] that he has committed a string of brutal murders during a bout of encephalitis, to throw him off the trail and keep himself safe. Dr. Lecter uses psychic driving by purposely inducing trance-like states during therapy session, using [[Will Graham (Character)|Will Graham's]] encephalitis, then reinforcing his delusions that he has killed during episodes of lost time where he can't remember his own actions.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pjZYDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT329&lpg=PT329&dq=psychic+driving+hannibal&source=bl&ots=02qst3vgab&sig=gBilnFmIISNgU0jG0Qm4YdhIqro&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwinisOJ2PLaAhXmllQKHS_nCWc4ChDoATABegQIABAt#v=onepage&q=psychic%20driving%20hannibal&f=false|title=Deleuze and the Animal|last=Gardner|first=Colin|date=2017-04-01|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|isbn=9781474422765|language=en}}</ref>

Accessories | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | location = [[Noida]], [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[India]] | homepage = {{URL|http://ringingbells.co.in|Ringing Bells}} (defunct) }} '''Ringing Bells Private Limited''' was a company based in [[Noida]] ([[India]]), registered on 16 September 2015.{{cite web | url=http://www.dnaindia.com/scitech/report-here-s-what-we-know-about-ringing-bells-the-company-behind-the-rs-500-smartphone-2178421 | title=Here’s what we know about Ringing Bells--the company behind the Rs 251 smartphone | publisher=[[Daily News and Analysis|Daily News and Analysis (DNA)]] | date=2016-02-16 | accessdate=2016-02-18}}Registration date, status, and the company CIN (U32204DL2015PTC285276) are for Indian companies obtained by running a query from the [[Ministry of Corporate Affairs|Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA)]] page http://www.mca.gov.in/DCAPortalWeb/ It was later described as a "[[ponzi scheme]]"{{Citation needed|reason=Your explanation here|date=April 2017}}. == Freedom 251 == The [[company]] attracted attention when it announced the [[Freedom 251]], a [[3G]] [[smartphone]], at a price of [[rupee|₹]] 251. That would make it the world's cheapest smartphone. Ringing Bells MD Mohit Goel claimed on 16 December 2016 that the company has already delivered 70000 phones and the remaining phones would be delivered soon.{{Cite news|url=http://tech.firstpost.com/amp/news-analysis/70000-freedom-251-smartphones-delivered-to-customers-clarifies-ringing-bells-md-mohit-goel-353301.html|title=Ringing Bells to import first 50 lakh phones: Govt. official|last=Bhargava|first=Yuthika|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-03-14|language=en}} ==Controversies== ===Scam allegations=== There are suggestions that the Freedom 251 sale is a scam.http://www.indiatimes.com/news/india/here-s-why-the-freedom-251-might-be-the-scammiest-scam-of-2016_-250897.html It is alleged that the phone looks like a Chinese phone with the original brand label covered with [[correction fluid|whitener]]. The icons shown on screen shots are copied from Apple's [[iPhone]]. MP [[Kirit Somaiya]] describes the offer as a "huge scam" and has asked the government of [[Uttar Pradesh]] to investigate.[http://indianexpress.com/article/technology/tech-news-technology/freedom-251-is-a-ponzi-scam-bjp-mp-kirit-somaiya/ "Freedom 251 is a ponzi scam: BJP MP Kirit Somaiya", ''Indian Express'', 20 February 2016]. Accessed 22 February 2016 As a result of these concerns, the payment gateway facilitator PayUBiz decided to withhold payment to Ringing Bells until the items were dispatched. In response, Ringing Bells stated that they would accept payment by cash-on-delivery for those customers who had placed orders but had been unable to make payment through the payment gateway before the offer closed.Tech Desk, [http://indianexpress.com/article/technology/tech-news-technology/ringing-bells-freedom-251-cash-on-delivery/ "Ringing Bells Freedom 251 now has cash on delivery option"], ''Indian Express'', 26 February 2016. Ringing Bells has also been accused of fraud and non-payment of dues by its customer services provider Cyfuture.http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/telecom/noida-based-bpo-cyfuture-files-police-complaint-against-ringing-bells/articleshow/51159346.cmshttp://www.ibnlive.com/news/tech/freedom-251-maker-ringing-bells-now-accused-of-cheating-and-fraud-by-its-customer-service-provider-1208076.htmlhttp://www.businesstoday.in/current/corporate/freedom-251-maker-ringing-bells-accused-of-fraud/story/229627.htmlhttp://indianexpress.com/photos/technology-gallery/ringing-bells-freedom-251-noida-police-registers-fir-cheating-everything-that-has-happened-so-far/3/ ===Arrest of Mohit Goel=== Goel was detained on 24 February 2017 over fraud allegations, after the owner of Ghaziabad-based Ayam Enterprises filed an FIR alleging that Ringing Bells "defrauded" it of Rs. 16 lakh.{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/tech/freedom-251-phone-ringing-bells-director-mohit-goel-detained-for-fraud/story-2IeBHycnvwkG5lYwx0XbPK.html|title=Mohit Goel, director of company that made Freedom 251 phones, detained for fraud|date=23 February 2017|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|accessdate=25 February 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/ringing-bells-freedom-251-cheapest-phone-maker-is-class-viii-fail-4542590/|title=‘Cheapest phone’ maker Mohit Goel is Class VIII fail: Cops|last=Vatsa|first=Aditi|date=25 February 2017|work=[[The Indian Express]]|accessdate=25 February 2017}} Mohit Goel has been arrested on allegations of fraud. Several analysts have described the phone as a "[[ponzi scheme]]".{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-39074037|title=India police arrest 'world's cheapest smartphone' firm boss|date=2017-02-24|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-03-14|language=en-GB}} Goel was again arrested by the Delhi Police on June 10, 2018 for allegedly extorting money in lieu of settling a rape case.{{Cite news|url=https://www.financialexpress.com/india-news/worlds-cheapest-smartphone-freedom-251-maker-ringing-bells-founder-mohit-goel-arrested-by-police/1200709/|title=World’s cheapest smartphone ‘Freedom 251’ maker Ringing Bells founder Mohit Goel arrested by police|date=2018-06-10|work=The Financial Express|access-date=2018-06-10|language=en-US}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{Corruption in India}} {{Scams and confidence tricks}} [[Category:Companies based in Noida]] [[Category:Electronics companies of India]] [[Category:Indian companies established in 2015]] [[Category:21st-century scandals]] [[Category:Cover-ups]] [[Category:Pyramid and Ponzi schemes]] [[Category:Confidence tricks]] [[Category:Corporate scandals]] [[Category:Criminal investigation]] [[Category:Deception]] [[Category:Financial scandals]] [[Category:Scandals in India]] [[Category:2017 scandals]]

{{notability|date=December 2012}}
'''Rural Alliances''' is an international project funded by the [[European Union]] through the [[Interreg]] ''North West Europe'' European Regional Development Fund IVB <ref>http://www.nweurope.eu/</ref> funding scheme aimed at bringing rural businesses together with their communities to stimulate local economies and services.
Twelve partner organisations from six different EU countries are working together. The twelve are:
'''Belgium''' *Boerenbondvereniging voor Projecten vzw *[[Vlaamse Landmaatschappij (VLM)]] (Flemish Land Agency)
'''France''' *[[Redon, Ille-et-Vilaine|Maison de l'Emploi, du Développement, de la Formation et de l'Insertion du Pays de Redon-Bretagne Sud]] (MEDEFI) *[[Laval, Mayenne]] Technopole (Laval & Mayenne Technology Park)
'''Germany''' *[[University of Marburg|Philipps Universität]], [[Marburg]]
'''Republic of Ireland''' *[[County Kerry|South Kerry Development Partnership Ltd.]] *[[Mayo County Council]]
'''Netherlands''' *Stichting Streekhuis Het Groene Woud & De Meierij *Stichting Streekhuis [[Kempenland]] *[[Lochem|Gemeente Lochem]]
'''United Kingdom''' *[[Brecon Beacons National Park|Brecon Beacons National Park Authority]] *[[University of Wales, Trinity Saint David]]
The project was initiated in 2011 with a meeting in [[Brecon]], [[Wales]]. A project officer is employed by the Brecon Beacons National Park Authority to develop clusters of activity in several areas of the park.<ref>http://www.rural-alliances.eu/</ref>
'''Alliance building Blueprint Prototype'''
The University Partners have been working closely with the partners to explore and develop concepts and frameworks to capture, record and share successful alliance building methods in order to develop an Alliance Building Blueprint. To begin this process, they held a Master Class with all the partners in February 2012 in Leuven, Belgium where key concepts were discussed and agreed, including debates on what constitutes a rural area, what is a community, and how many members are needed to make up an Alliance. This was followed up with research, interviews and further workshops with the partners to explore alliance building methods in the different areas.
At this early stage in the project an outline concept has been developed. This shows a cyclic phase from building the alliance, its management, reviewing its development and growth, and looking towards long-term planning.
---abbp---
Key components include a good contact database; a method of plotting the skills and capacity that exist in the alliance or in the wider community; creating an atmosphere of open dialogue; identifying and supporting champions who are visionary and “get things done”, and a good understanding of local context, what other initiatives are competing, what are the risks and what are the rewards.
This concept will now be developed and modified through case studies on the different alliances in 2013/4 to explore the methods used to make them successful. Research will be done to assess how useful tools and techniques can be transferred between alliances, to ensure that lessons are being learned and communicated across the partnership, and monitoring and evaluation will take place to ensure the viability, usefulness and relevance of the Blueprint model.
'''Rural Vibrancy Measuring Index (RVMI)'''
The Rural Vibrancy Measuring Index is a tool that is currently being developed by the University partners of the Rural Alliances project. The current stage of the RVMI represents the outcomes of several transnational workshops, the evaluation of partner questionnaires and further literature research. The purpose of this index is to give local communities a tool to determine their vibrancy. Using the RVMI should allow local communities to acquire knowledge on the strengths and weaknesses of their community and help them to allocate their resources more efficiently and develop their community.
'''Definition ‘Rural Vibrancy''''
‘Rural Vibrancy’ describes the nature of a rural community, which is characterized by active involvement and the creative, dynamic interaction of people from different groupings with the capacity to create common objectives and to act jointly to develop their community. It is desirable from the perspective of the Rural Alliances consortium that vibrant rural communities follow the aim to develop and/or maintain social, cultural and economic benefit, adapt to change and improve quality of life for everyone within the community.
'''RVMI categories'''
The analytical subject of the RVMI is an analysis of local community groups that are formed within a specific area. The RVMI focusses on local community groups because they are the origin and the basis of ‘vibrancy’, being the organisational form of people that act jointly. Depending on the actions the community groups take (e.g. cooperation) they can make a place more or less vibrant. On the basis of this pattern the RVMI proposes a ‘catalogue’ of quantitative and qualitative questions on the role of community groups that can be visualized and interpreted. The first field tests are scheduled for early 2013.
'''Contribution to rural development'''
The main goal of the Rural Alliances project is to develop a transnational tool to capture rural vibrancy. Approaches like quality of life<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Quality of Life|url = http://econpapers.repec.org/bookchap/oxpobooks/9780198287971.htm|date = 1993-01-01|first = Martha|last = Nussbaum|first2 = Amartya|last2 = Sen}}</ref> or vibrant communities refer to a presence of certain amenities and measure hard and soft location factors. A vibrant countryside<ref>{{Cite web|title = [ARCHIVED CONTENT] Defra, UK; Rural Affairs - Rural Strategy|url = http://defra.gov.uk/rural/strategy/default.htm|archive-url = http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20050301193120/http://defra.gov.uk/rural/strategy/default.htm|dead-url = yes|archive-date = 2005-03-01|website = webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk|accessdate = 2015-07-31}}</ref> is one of the main categories of the English Rural White Paper<ref>{{Cite web|title = [ARCHIVED CONTENT] Defra, UK; Rural White Paper: Our Countryside: The Future - A Fair Deal for Rural England|url = http://defra.gov.uk/rural/ruralwp/default.htm|archive-url = http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20050301193120/http://defra.gov.uk/rural/ruralwp/default.htm|dead-url = yes|archive-date = 2005-03-01|website = webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk|accessdate = 2015-07-31}}</ref> and relates to community involvement and activity. It distinguishes between vibrant, active, barely active, and sleeping parishes assessed on numbers of meeting places, voluntary and cultural activities, as well as contested parish elections. Together with a living, working and protected countryside the vibrant countryside is seen as part of a sustainable rural development. Community involvement, participation and inhabitants’ perceptions need to be integrated in such instruments. Therefore, vibrant rural communities follow the aim to develop and/or maintain social, cultural and economic benefit, adapt to change and improve quality of life for everyone within the community. This development is on-going, iterative and inclusive. Taking various national frames, cultural backgrounds, social behaviours and personal opinions into consideration lead to a broadly agreed definition, approach and implementation process. A rural development instrument is created by the transnational partnership. This is called Rural Vibes.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Rural Vibes|url = http://www.ruralvibes.eu/|website = www.ruralvibes.eu|accessdate = 2015-07-31}}</ref>
